While we believe we have identified the key risk factors affecting our business, there may be additional risks and uncertainties that are not presently known or that are not currently believed to be significant that may adversely affect our results of operations.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	We intend to reduce costs to improve our profitability.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Our EDG and Canvys businesses generated modest operating income during fiscal 2011.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P0_S3	With the closing of the Transaction, we are taking actions to re-align our cost structure to fit the remaining businesses.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Our ability to complete these actions may be limited by a variety of factors.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P0_S5	Cost-reduction actions to achieve our cost reduction objectives could have the effect of reducing our talent pool and available resources whether or not achieved, and, consequently, could affect our ability to serve customers and to hire and retain key personnel.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We maintain a significant investment in inventory.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P1_S1	We have also incurred significant charges for inventory obsolescence, and may incur similar charges in the future.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We maintain significant inventories in an effort to ensure that customers have a reliable source of supply.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	The market for many of our products is characterized by rapid change as a result of the development of new technologies, evolving industry standards, and frequent new product introductions by some of our customers.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	We do not have many long-term supply contracts with our customers.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	If we fail to anticipate the changing needs of our customers and accurately forecast our customer demands, our customers may not continue to place orders with us, and we may accumulate significant inventories of products which we will be unable to sell or return to our vendors.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P2_S4	This may result in a significant decline in the value of our inventory.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We face competitive pressure in the markets we serve.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We face many competitors, both global and local, in the markets we serve.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Our overall competitive position depends on a number of factors including price, engineering capability, vendor representation, product diversity, lead times and the level of customer service.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our competition includes hundreds of electronic component distributors of various sizes, locations, and market focuses, as well as original equipment manufacturers and refurbishers.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Some of our competitors have greater resources and broader name recognition than we do.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S5	As a result, these competitors may be able to better withstand changing conditions within our markets and throughout the economy as a whole.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P3_S6	Increased competition may result in price reductions, reduced margins, or a loss of market share, any of which could materially and adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	EDG is dependent on a limited number of vendors to supply it with essential products.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Electron tubes and certain other products supplied by EDG are currently produced by a relatively small number of manufacturers.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Our success depends, in large part, on maintaining current vendor relationships and developing new relationships.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P4_S3	We believe that vendors supplying products to some of the product lines of EDG are consolidating their distribution relationships or exiting the business.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P4_S4	To the extent that our significant suppliers reduce the amount of products they sell through distribution are unwilling to continue to do business with us, or are unable to continue to meet or significantly alter their obligations to us, such as by extending lead times, limiting supplies, or other factors, there could be a material adverse effect on our business.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P4_S5	Economic, political, and other risks associated with international sales and operations could adversely affect our results of operations.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Because we sell and source our products worldwide, our business is subject to risks associated with doing business internationally.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	In addition, many of our employees, suppliers, and warehouse facilities are located outside the United States.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Accordingly, our future results could be harmed by a variety of factors including:
355948_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	geopolitical turmoil, including terrorism, war, or natural disasters, may negatively affect our results from operations Our products may be found to be defective and, as a result, warranty and/or product liability claims may be asserted against us.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We sell many of our components at prices that are significantly lower than the cost of the equipment or other goods in which they are incorporated.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Since a defect or failure in a product could give rise to failures in the end products that incorporate them, we may face claims for damages that are disproportionate to the revenues and profits we receive from the components involved in the claims.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P8_S2	While we typically have provisions in our agreements with our suppliers that hold the supplier accountable for defective products, and we and our suppliers generally exclude consequential damages in our standard terms and conditions, our ability to avoid such liabilities may be limited as a result of various factors, including the inability to exclude such damages due to the laws of some of the countries where we do business.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Our business could be materially adversely affected as a result of a significant quality or performance issue in the components sold by us if we are required to pay for the damages that result.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Although we have product liability insurance, such insurance is limited in coverage and amount.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	A single stockholder has voting control over us.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	As of July 22, 2011, Edward J. Richardson, our Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President, beneficially owned approximately 99% of the outstanding shares of our Class B common stock, representing approximately 67% of the voting power of the outstanding common stock.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P10_S2	This share ownership permits Mr. Richardson to exert control over the outcome of most stockholder votes, including votes concerning the election of directors, by-law amendments, possible mergers, corporate control contests, and other significant corporate transactions.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Foreign currency exchange rates may materially affect our results.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Since a significant portion of our business is conducted outside the U.S., we face exposure to movements in non-U.S. currency exchange rates, which may harm our results of operations.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Price increases caused by currency exchange rate fluctuations may make our products less competitive or have an adverse effect on our margins.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our international revenues and expenses generally are derived from sales and operations in currencies other than the U.S. dollar.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Accordingly, when the U.S. dollar strengthens in relation to the currencies of the countries in which we sell our products, our U.S. dollar reported net revenue and income will decrease.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	We currently do not engage in any currency hedging transactions.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P12_S3	We cannot predict whether foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries will have a material adverse effect on our operations and financial results in the future.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Substantial defaults by our customers on our accounts receivable or the loss of significant customers could have a significant negative impact on our business.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	A significant portion of our working capital consists of accounts receivable from customers.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	If customers with a significant accounts receivable balance were to become insolvent or otherwise unable to pay for products and services, or were to become unwilling or unable to make payments in a timely manner, our business, results of operations, financial condition, or liquidity could be adversely affected.

355948_11_ITEM1A_P15_S2	In addition, we may not obtain the expected benefits or cost savings from acquisitions.

355948_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	If any of these risks materialize, they may result in disruptions to our business and the diversion of management time and attention, which could increase the costs of operating our existing or acquired businesses or negate the expected benefits of the acquisitions.

355948_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	In addition, control procedures are designed to reduce rather than eliminate business risks.
355948_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	If we fail to maintain an effective system of internal controls, or if management or our independent registered public accounting firm discovers material weaknesses in our internal controls, we may be unable to produce reliable financial reports or prevent fraud.

355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Business Overview Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is incorporated in the state of Delaware.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	We are a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables, and customized display solutions, serving customers in the RF and microwave communications, military, marine, aviation, industrial, scientific, and medical markets.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S2	Our strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S3	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S4	Our products include semiconductor fabrication equipment, electron tubes, microwave generators, and visual technology solutions.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S5	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, and communication applications.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S6	On March 1, 2011, we completed the sale of the assets primarily used or held for use in, and certain liabilities of RFPD, as well as certain other Company assets, including our information technology assets, to Arrow in exchange for $238.8 million, which included an estimated pre-closing working capital adjustment of approximately $27.0 million.
355948_11_ITEM7_P3_S7	The final purchase price is subject to a post-closing working capital adjustment.
355948_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	On June 29, 2011, we received notification from Arrow seeking a post-closing working capital adjustment, which would reduce the purchase price by approximately $4.2 million.
355948_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	The $4.2 million is included in our results from discontinued operations for the fiscal year ended May 28, 2011.
355948_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	We have two continuing operating segments, which we define as follows: Electron Device Group ( EDG ) provides engineered solutions and distributes electronic components to customers in diverse markets including the steel, automotive, textile, plastics, semiconductor manufacturing, and broadcast industries.
355948_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	Canvys provides global integrated display solutions serving the financial, corporate enterprise, healthcare, industrial and medical OEM markets.

355948_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ) requires management to make significant estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
355948_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	Management continuously evaluates the significant estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, inventory obsolescence, goodwill impairment testing, income taxes, contingencies, and litigation.
355948_11_ITEM7_P41_S2	Management bases the estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, however, actual results could differ from those estimates.
355948_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	The policies discussed below are considered by management to be critical to understanding our financial position and results of operations.
355948_11_ITEM7_P42_S1	Their application involves significant judgments and estimates in preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
355948_11_ITEM7_P42_S2	For all of these policies, management cautions that future events rarely develop exactly as forecasted, and the best estimates routinely require adjustment.
355948_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts Our allowance for doubtful accounts includes estimated losses that result from uncollectible receivables.
355948_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	aging of receivables, individually and in the aggregate; a large number of customers which are widely dispersed across geographic areas; collectability and delinquency history by geographic area; and the fact that no single customer accounts for more than 10% of net sales.
355948_11_ITEM7_P44_S1	Significant changes in one or more of these considerations may require adjustments affecting net income and net carrying value of accounts receivable.
355948_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts was approximately $0.4 million and $0.4 million as of May 28, 2011, and May 29, 2010, respectively.
355948_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	Impairment of Investments We hold a portfolio of investment securities and periodically assess its recoverability.
355948_11_ITEM7_P46_S1	In the event of a decline in fair value of an investment, judgment is made whether the decline is other than temporary.
355948_11_ITEM7_P46_S2	Management s assessment as to the nature of a decline is largely based on the duration of that market decline, financial health of and specific prospects for the issuer, and our cash requirements and intent to hold the investment.
355948_11_ITEM7_P46_S3	If an investment is impaired and the decline in market value is considered to be other than temporary, an appropriate write-down is recorded.
355948_11_ITEM7_P46_S4	We recognized investment impairment charges of less than $0.1 million during fiscal 2009.
355948_11_ITEM7_P46_S5	We did not recognize any investment impairment charges during fiscal 2011 and 2010.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	Our product sales are recognized as revenue upon shipment, when title passes to the customer, when delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, and when collectability is reasonably assured.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S1	Our sales are recorded net of discounts and returns based on our historical experience.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S2	Our products are often manufactured to meet the specific design needs of our customers applications.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S3	Our engineers work closely with customers to ensure that our products will meet their needs.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S4	Our customers are under no obligation to compensate us for designing the products we sell.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S5	In a limited number of cases, we provide and bill our customers with non-product related services, such as testing, calibration, non-recurring engineering, tooling, and installation services.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S6	We have concluded that the service revenue should not be considered a separate unit of accounting from the product sale as we have determined there is no objective and reliable evidence of the fair value of the undelivered items.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S7	We have also concluded that, in the limited cases where remaining obligations exist after delivery of the product, the obligation relative to the unit of accounting is inconsequential or perfunctory.
355948_11_ITEM7_P47_S8	This conclusion was reached based on the following facts: the timing of any remaining obligation is agreed upon with the customer, which in most cases, is performed immediately after the delivery of the product; the cost and time involved to complete the remaining obligation is minimal, the costs and time do not vary significantly; we have a demonstrated history of completing the remaining obligations timely; and finally, failure to complete the remaining obligation does not enable the customer to receive a full or partial refund of the product or the service.
355948_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	Inventories Our worldwide inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market, generally using a weighted-average cost method.
355948_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	Our inventories included $28.0 million of finished goods and $2.9 million of raw materials and work-in-progress.
355948_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	Provisions for obsolete or slow moving inventories are recorded based upon regular analysis of stock rotation privileges, obsolescence, the exiting of certain market segments, and assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
355948_11_ITEM7_P49_S1	If future demand, changes in the industry, or market conditions differ from management s estimates, additional provisions may be necessary.
355948_11_ITEM7_P49_S2	We recorded provisions to our inventory reserves of $1.1 million, $0.2 million, and $7.6 million during fiscal 2011, 2010, and 2009, respectively, which were included in cost of sales.
355948_11_ITEM7_P49_S3	The provisions were principally for obsolete and slow moving parts.
355948_11_ITEM7_P49_S4	The parts were written down to estimated realizable value.
355948_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	In accordance with ASC 205-20, Presentation of Financial Statements Discontinued Operations ( ASC 205-20 ), we reported the financial results of RFPD as a discontinued operation.
355948_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	Refer to Note 4 Discontinued Operations of our notes to our consolidated financial statements for additional discussion on the sale of RFPD.
355948_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	We accrue a liability for loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
355948_11_ITEM7_P51_S1	When only a range of a possible loss can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_11_ITEM7_P51_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	Long-Lived Assets We periodically evaluate the recoverability of the carrying amounts of our long-lived assets, including software, property, plant and equipment.
355948_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	We assess in accordance with ASC 360-10, Property, Plant, and Equipment Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets ( ASC 360-10 ), the possibility of long-lived assets being impaired when events trigger the likelihood.
355948_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	Impairment is assessed when the expected cash flows to be derived from an asset are less than its carrying amount.
355948_11_ITEM7_P54_S1	If impairment exists, the carrying value of the impaired asset is reduced to its net realizable value.
355948_11_ITEM7_P54_S2	The impairment charge is recorded in operating results.
355948_11_ITEM7_P54_S3	The results of our impairment tests for fiscal 2011 and 2010 indicated no impairment of our long-lived assets.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	Warranties We offer warranties for the limited number of specific products we manufacture.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	We also provide extended warranties for some products we sell that lengthen the period of coverage specified in the manufacturer s original warranty.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S2	Our warranty terms generally range from one to three years.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S3	We estimate the cost to perform under the warranty obligation and recognize this estimated cost at the time of the related product sale.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S4	We record expense related to our warranty obligations as cost of sales in our consolidated statements of operations.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S5	Each quarter, we assess actual warranty costs incurred on a product-by-product basis and compare the warranty costs to our estimated warranty obligation.
355948_11_ITEM7_P55_S6	With respect to new products, estimates are based generally on knowledge of the products, the extended warranty period, and warranty experience.
355948_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	Warranty reserves are established for costs that are expected to be incurred after the sale and delivery of products under warranty.
355948_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	Warranty reserves are included in accrued liabilities on our consolidated balance sheets.
355948_11_ITEM7_P56_S2	The warranty reserves are determined based on known product failures, historical experience, and other available evidence.
355948_11_ITEM7_P56_S3	See Note 3 Significant Accounting Policies of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further information.
355948_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	Stock Compensation Effective June 4, 2006, we adopted ASC 718-10, Compensation Stock Compensation ( ASC 718 ), which requires the measurement and recognition of compensation cost at fair value for all share-based payments, including stock options.
355948_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	We estimate fair value using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, which requires assumptions such as expected volatility, risk-free interest rate, expected life, and dividends.
355948_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	See Note 3 Significant Accounting Policies of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further information.
355948_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	Income Taxes We recognize deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the differences between financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of assets and liabilities.
355948_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	We regularly review our deferred tax assets for recoverability and determine the need for a valuation allowance based on a number of factors, including both positive and negative evidence.
355948_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	These factors include historical taxable income or loss, projected future taxable income or loss, the expected timing of the reversals of existing temporary differences, and the implementation of tax planning strategies.
355948_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	In circumstances where we, or any of our affiliates, have incurred three years of cumulative losses which constitute significant negative evidence, positive evidence of equal or greater significance is needed to overcome the negative evidence before a tax benefit is recognized for deductible temporary differences and loss carryforwards.
355948_11_ITEM7_P60_S4	See Note 8 Income Taxes of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further information.
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	New Accounting Pronouncements In May 2011, the FASB issued ASC Update No. 2011-05, Comprehensive Income: Presentation of Comprehensive Income, ( ASC Update No. 2011-05 ) .
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S1	This amends the FASB Accounting Standards Codification to allow an entity the option to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements.
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S2	In both choices, an entity is required to present each component of net income along with the total net income, each component of other comprehensive income along with a total for other comprehensive income, and a total amount for comprehensive income.
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S3	ASU Update No. 2011-05 eliminates the option to present the components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in stockholders equity.
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S4	The amendments to the Codification in the ASU do not change the items that must be reported in other comprehensive income or when an item of other comprehensive income must be reclassified to net income.
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S5	ASU Update No. 2011-05 should be applied retrospectively.
355948_11_ITEM7_P61_S6	No. 2011-05 during our third quarter of fiscal 2012.
355948_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued ASC update No 2009-13, Revenue Recognition, ( ASC Update No. 2009-13 ), which addresses the accounting for multiple-deliverable arrangements to enable vendors to account for products or services (deliverables) separately rather than as a combined unit.
355948_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	Specifically, the guidance amends the criteria in FASB ASC Subtopic 605-25, Revenue Recognition-Multiple-Element Arrangements, for separating consideration in multiple-deliverable arrangements.
355948_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	The guidance establishes a selling price hierarchy for determining the selling price of a deliverable, which is based on: ( a ) vendor-specific objective evidence; ( b ) third-party evidence; or ( c ) estimates.
355948_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	The guidance also eliminates the residual method of allocation and requires that arrangement consideration be allocated at the inception of the arrangement to all deliverables using the relative selling price method.
355948_11_ITEM7_P63_S2	In addition, the guidance significantly expands required disclosures related to a vendor s multiple-deliverable revenue arrangements.
355948_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	ASC Update No. 2009-13 is effective prospectively for revenue arrangements entered into or materially modified in fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010.
355948_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	The adoption of this guidance did not have a significant impact on our consolidated financial position or results of operations.

Foreign Currency Exposure Even though we take into account current foreign currency exchange rates at the time an order is taken, our financial statements denominated in a non-U.S. functional currency are subject to foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P0_S4	Our foreign denominated assets and liabilities are cash, accounts receivable, inventory, accounts payable, and intercompany receivables and payables, as we conduct business in countries of the European Union, Asia/Pacific and, to a lesser extent, Canada and Latin America.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P0_S5	We could manage foreign exchange exposures by using currency clauses in sales contracts, local debt to offset asset exposures, and forward contracts to hedge significant transactions.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P0_S6	We have not entered into any forward contracts in fiscal 2011, fiscal 2010, or fiscal 2009.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Had the U.S. dollar changed unfavorably 10% against various foreign currencies, foreign denominated net sales would have been lower by an estimated $15.7 million during fiscal 2011 and an estimated $13.2 million during fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Total assets would have declined by an estimated $29.4 million as of the fiscal year ended May 28, 2011, and an estimated $28.6 million as of the fiscal year ended May 29, 2010, while the total liabilities would have decreased by an estimated $1.5 million as of the fiscal year ended May 28, 2011, and an estimated $1.7 million as of the fiscal year ended May 29, 2010.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The interpretation and analysis of these disclosures should not be considered in isolation since such variances in interest rates and exchanges rates would likely influence other economic factors.
355948_11_ITEM7A_P2_S1	Such factors, which are not readily quantifiable, would likely also affect our operations.

355948_11_ITEM8_P0_S1	DESCRIPTION OF THE COMPANY Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is incorporated in the state of Delaware.
355948_11_ITEM8_P0_S2	We are a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables, and customized display solutions serving customers in the RF and microwave communications, military, marine, aviation, industrial, scientific, and medical markets.
355948_11_ITEM8_P0_S3	Utilizing its core engineering and manufacturing capabilities, our strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions.
355948_11_ITEM8_P0_S4	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair.
355948_11_ITEM8_P0_S5	Our products include power semiconductors, electron tubes, microwave generators, and visual technology solutions.
355948_11_ITEM8_P0_S6	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, and communication applications.

355948_11_ITEM8_P2_S1	On an ongoing basis, management evaluates the significant estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, inventory obsolescence, goodwill impairment testing, income taxes, contingencies, and litigation.

355948_11_ITEM8_P23_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.

355948_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	Share-Based Compensation: We measure and recognize compensation cost at fair value for all share-based payments, including stock options.
355948_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	We estimate fair value using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, which requires assumptions such as expected volatility, risk-free interest rate, expected life, and dividends.
355948_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	Compensation cost is recognized using a graded-vesting schedule over the applicable vesting period, or date on which retirement eligibility is achieved, if shorter (non-substantive vesting period approach).
355948_11_ITEM8_P26_S1	Share-based compensation expense totaled approximately $1.2 million during fiscal 2011 and $0.6 million during both fiscal 2010 and 2009.

355948_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	Earnings per Share: We have authorized 30,000,000 shares of common stock, 10,000,000 shares of Class B common stock, and 5,000,000 shares of preferred stock.
355948_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	The Class B common stock has 10 votes per share and has transferability restrictions; however, Class B common stock may be converted into common stock on a share-for-share basis at any time.
355948_11_ITEM8_P40_S2	With respect to dividends and distributions, shares of common stock and Class B common stock rank equally and have the same rights, except that Class B common stock cash dividends are limited to 90% of the amount of Class A common stock cash dividends.
355948_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	In accordance with ASC 260-10, Earnings Per Share ( ASC 260 ), our Class B common stock is considered a participating security requiring the use of the two-class method for the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share.
355948_11_ITEM8_P41_S1	The two-class computation method for each period reflects the cash dividends paid per share for each class of stock, plus the amount of allocated undistributed earnings per share computed using the participation percentage which reflects the dividend rights of each class of stock.
355948_11_ITEM8_P41_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were computed using the two-class method as prescribed in ASC 260.
355948_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	The shares of Class B common stock are considered to be participating convertible securities since the shares of Class B common stock are convertible on a share-for-share basis into shares of common stock and may participate in dividends with common stock according to a predetermined formula which is 90% of the amount of Class A common stock cash dividends.
355948_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income, adjusted for interest savings, net of tax, on assumed conversion of convertible debentures and notes, by the actual shares outstanding and share equivalents that would arise from the exercise of stock options, certain restricted stock awards, and the assumed conversion of convertible debentures and notes when dilutive.
355948_11_ITEM8_P43_S1	For fiscal 2011, our 7 3 / 4 % Notes were repurchased, thus eliminating any effect from the dilutive calculation.
355948_11_ITEM8_P43_S2	For fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2009, the assumed conversion and the effect of the interest savings of our 7 3 / 4 % Notes were excluded because their inclusion would have been anti-dilutive.
355948_11_ITEM8_P43_S3	For fiscal 2010 and fiscal 2009, the weighted-average number of shares used to calculate diluted earnings per share is equal to the basic weighted average shares due to the loss from continuing operations during these periods.

355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) (in thousands, except per share amounts) New Accounting Pronouncements: In May 2011, the FASB issued ASC Update No. 2011-05, Comprehensive Income: Presentation of Comprehensive Income, ( ASC Update No. 2011-05 ) .
355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	This amends the FASB Accounting Standards Codification to allow an entity the option to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements.
355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S2	In both choices, an entity is required to present each component of net income along with the total net income, each component of other comprehensive income along with a total for other comprehensive income, and a total amount for comprehensive income.
355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S3	ASU Update No. 2011-05 eliminates the option to present the components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in stockholders equity.
355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S4	The amendments to the Codification in the ASU do not change the items that must be reported in other comprehensive income or when an item of other comprehensive income must be reclassified to net income.
355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S5	ASU Update No. 2011-05 should be applied retrospectively.
355948_11_ITEM8_P46_S6	For public entities, the amendments are effective for fiscal years, and interim period within those years, beginning after December 15, 2011, and as such we will adopt ASC Update No. 2011-05 during our third quarter fiscal 2012.
355948_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	In October 2009, the FASB issued ASC update No 2009-13, Revenue Recognition, ( ASC Update No. 2009-13 ), which addresses the accounting for multiple-deliverable arrangements to enable vendors to account for products or services (deliverables) separately rather than as a combined unit.
355948_11_ITEM8_P47_S1	Specifically, the guidance amends the criteria in FASB ASC Subtopic 605-25, Revenue Recognition-Multiple-Element Arrangements, for separating consideration in multiple-deliverable arrangements.
355948_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	The guidance establishes a selling price hierarchy for determining the selling price of a deliverable, which is based on: ( a ) vendor-specific objective evidence; ( b ) third-party evidence; or ( c ) estimates.
355948_11_ITEM8_P48_S1	The guidance also eliminates the residual method of allocation and requires that arrangement consideration be allocated at the inception of the arrangement to all deliverables using the relative selling price method.
355948_11_ITEM8_P48_S2	In addition, the guidance significantly expands required disclosures related to a vendor s multiple-deliverable revenue arrangements.
355948_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	ASC Update No. 2009-13 is effective prospectively for revenue arrangements entered into or materially modified in fiscal years beginning on or after June 15, 2010.
355948_11_ITEM8_P49_S1	The adoption of this guidance did not have a significant impact on our consolidated financial position or results of operations.

DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS Arrow Transaction On October 1, 2010, we entered into an agreement with Arrow, where Arrow agreed to acquire all of the assets primarily used or held for use in, and certain liabilities of RFPD, as well as certain other Company assets, including our information technology assets in exchange for $210.0 million, subsequently re-negotiated to $211.8 million, subject to the purposed working capital adjustment.

355948_11_ITEM8_P51_S3	The cash bonus compensation amount awarded was approximately $3.8 million and was recorded as expense from discontinued operations during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.

355948_11_ITEM8_P91_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures ( ASC 820 ), defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
355948_11_ITEM8_P91_S1	ASC 820 establishes a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
355948_11_ITEM8_P92_S0	defined as inputs other than quoted prices in active markets that are either directly or indirectly observable; and Level 3, defined as unobservable inputs in which little or no market data exists; therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions.

355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders of Richardson Electronics, Ltd.
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S1	We have audited Richardson Electronics Ltd s, internal control over financial reporting as of May 28, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S2	Richardson Electronics Ltd. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S4	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S6	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
355948_11_ITEM8_P99_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
355948_11_ITEM8_P100_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
355948_11_ITEM8_P100_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
355948_11_ITEM8_P100_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
355948_11_ITEM8_P100_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
355948_11_ITEM8_P100_S4	In our opinion, Richardson Electronics, Ltd. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of May 28, 2011, based on the COSO criteria .
355948_11_ITEM8_P100_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Richardson Electronics, Ltd. as of May 28, 2011 and May 29, 2010, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended May 28, 2011 of Richardson Electronics, Ltd., and our report dated July 22, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
355948_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act )) as of May 28, 2011.

355948_11_ITEM13_P36_S0	Fiscal 2011 Sales Up 17.4%, Net Income of $90.1 Million Cash and Investments of $239.7 Million LaFox, IL, July 20, 2011: Richardson Electronics, Ltd. (NASDAQ: RELL) today reported sales and earnings for its fourth quarter and fiscal year ended May 28, 2011.
355948_11_ITEM13_P36_S1	The Company also announced that its Board of Directors increased its share repurchase authorization and declared a $.05 quarterly cash dividend.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S0	Fiscal 2011 Results Net sales for Fiscal 2011 were $158.9 million, up 17.4% from net sales of $135.4 million for Fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S1	Gross margin decreased to 29.0% during Fiscal 2011, compared to 30.5% during Fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S2	Operating expenses were $43.3 million, compared to $43.2 million during Fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S3	Operating income for Fiscal 2011 was $2.8 million or 1.8% of net sales, compared to an operating loss in Fiscal 2010 of $1.9 million.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S4	Net income for Fiscal 2011 was $90.1 million, or $4.95 per diluted common share, compared to net income for Fiscal 2010 of $16.1 million or $0.92 per diluted common share.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S5	Net income for Fiscal 2011 includes income from discontinued operations of $88.1 million, which includes the net gain on sale of $111.4 million.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S6	Net sales for the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2011 were $40.7 million, up 4.9% from net sales of $38.8 million during the fourth quarter of last year.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S7	Gross profit for the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2011 was $11.4 million, compared to $10.9 million during the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S8	Operating expenses for the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2011 was $10.8 million, respectively, compared to $11.5 million during the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S9	Gross profit of $11.4 million during the fourth quarter includes approximately $1.0 million of expense related to additional inventory reserve provisions.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S10	Operating expenses of $10.8 million includes non-recurring costs related to a strategic distribution agreement of approximately $1.0 million.
355948_11_ITEM13_P37_S11	Reported operating income for the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2011 was $0.6 million, compared to an operating loss of $0.6 million during last year s fourth quarter.
355948_11_ITEM13_P38_S0	Following the completion of the sale of the RF, Wireless and Power Division (RFPD) to Arrow Electronics on March 1, 2011, we immediately began restructuring our costs for the remaining businesses.
355948_11_ITEM13_P38_S1	Excluding the non-recurring costs recorded during our fourth quarter of Fiscal 2011, we achieved our near-term operating margin target.
355948_11_ITEM13_P38_S2	With these non-recurring costs behind us, we are well-positioned to deliver strong operating performance in Fiscal 2012, said Edward J. Richardson, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President.
355948_11_ITEM13_P39_S0	Gross margin as a percentage of net sales decreased to 27.9% during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 compared to 28.2% during the fourth quarter of last year.
355948_11_ITEM13_P39_S1	Gross margin included expense of approximately $1.0 million related to additional inventory reserve provisions.
355948_11_ITEM13_P40_S0	SG A expenses during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 were $10.8 million, or 26.5% of net sales, compared to $11.5 million, or 29.7% of net sales, during the fourth quarter of last year.
355948_11_ITEM13_P40_S1	The fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 includes non-recurring costs related to a strategic distribution agreement of approximately $1.0 million.
355948_11_ITEM13_P41_S0	Operating income during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 was $0.6 million, or 1.4% of net sales, compared to a loss of $0.6 million, for the fourth quarter last year.
355948_11_ITEM13_P42_S0	Income from continuing operations during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 was $1.1 million, compared to a loss from continuing operations of $0.9 million during the fourth quarter of last year.
355948_11_ITEM13_P43_S0	Income from discontinued operations, net of tax, was $64.9 million, or $3.54 per diluted common share, during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 compared to $7.5 million, or $0.42 per diluted common share, during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2010.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S0	Net income during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011 was $66.0 million, or $3.60 per diluted common share, compared to net income of $6.6 million, or $0.38 per diluted common share, in the prior year s fourth quarter.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S1	CASH USED FOR SHARE REPURCHASES Total cash and investments as of fiscal year end were $239.7 million.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S2	In addition, we repurchased 645,900 shares for approximately $8.7 million during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S3	With our strong balance sheet, we are committed to returning value to our shareholders through a combination of cash dividends, continued share repurchases and investments to fund our growth initiatives, said Mr. Richardson.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S4	To date, the company has repurchased a total of 1.2 million shares.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S5	As of today, $34 million remains under our existing share repurchase authorization from the company s board of directors.
355948_11_ITEM13_P44_S6	This includes an incremental $25 million repurchase authorization approved by the board of directors on July 19, 2011.
355948_11_ITEM13_P45_S0	Share repurchases may be made on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions from time to time, subject to market conditions and trading restrictions.
355948_11_ITEM13_P45_S1	This authorization has no expiration and can be cancelled at any time.
355948_11_ITEM13_P46_S0	OUTLOOK EDG continues to experience strong sales growth as we benefit from strength within the global manufacturing sector as well as the incremental volume related to a strategic distribution agreement.
355948_11_ITEM13_P46_S1	The sales organization for Canvys is now clearly focused on winning design-in work with Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs).
355948_11_ITEM13_P46_S2	While the sell cycle for OEMs tends to be longer, these customers better align with our long-term strategy and value proposition, said Mr. Richardson.
355948_11_ITEM13_P46_S3	We expect that sales for EDG and Canvys for the first quarter to be in the range of $41 million to $43 million, up 9% to 15% over the prior year, and sales for Fiscal 2012 should be in the range of $170 to $175 million, up 7% to 10% over Fiscal 2011.
355948_11_ITEM13_P46_S4	We are also confident that we will be able to achieve our operating margin target for the year of 5%, concluded Mr. Richardson.
355948_11_ITEM13_P46_S5	The Company also announced today that its Board of Directors voted to declare a $0.05 dividend per share to all holders of common stock and a $0.045 cash dividend per share to all holders of Class B common stock.

355948_11_ITEM15_P1_S0	( we , us , the Company , and our ) is incorporated in the state of Delaware.
355948_11_ITEM15_P2_S0	We are a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables, and customized display solutions, serving customers in the radio frequency ( RF ) and microwave communications, military, marine, aviation, industrial, scientific, and medical markets.
355948_11_ITEM15_P2_S1	Our strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_11_ITEM15_P2_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair.
355948_11_ITEM15_P2_S3	Our products include semiconductor fabrication equipment, electron tubes, microwave generators, and visual technology solutions.
355948_11_ITEM15_P2_S4	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, and communication applications.

355948_11_ITEM15_P6_S0	We have two continuing operating segments, which we define as follows: Electron Device Group ( EDG ) provides engineered solutions and distributes electronic components to customers in diverse markets including the steel, automotive, textile, plastics, semiconductor manufacturing, avionics, and broadcast equipment industries.
355948_11_ITEM15_P7_S0	Canvys provides global integrated display solutions serving the financial, corporate enterprise, healthcare, industrial, and medical original equipment manufacturer ( OEM ) markets.
355948_11_ITEM15_P7_S1	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions:
355948_11_ITEM15_P8_S0	Selected financial data attributable to each segment and geographic region for fiscal 2011, 2010, and 2009 is set forth in Note 10 Segment and Geographic Information of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K. Electron Device Group EDG manufactures and distributes electron tubes, microwave generators, vacuum capacitors and related components and sub-assemblies.
355948_11_ITEM15_P8_S1	EDG also provides engineered solutions consisting of design and assembly services, component modification and development of customer-specific solutions, designed to fit unique applications.
355948_11_ITEM15_P9_S0	EDG serves customers in diverse markets including manufacturers and users of equipment in the steel, automotive, textile, plastics, semiconductor manufacturing, avionics, and broadcast equipment industries.
355948_11_ITEM15_P9_S1	We design solutions and provide components for applications such as industrial heating, laser technology, semiconductor manufacturing, radar, and welding.
355948_11_ITEM15_P9_S2	Typically, our engineered solutions and products are used in applications requiring high power and high frequency.
355948_11_ITEM15_P9_S3	We provide our solutions and products to original manufacturers of systems and equipment requiring such high power or high frequency and provide replacement products to the industrial end-users of such systems and equipment.
355948_11_ITEM15_P9_S4	We represent and support leading manufacturers of electron tubes and microwave devices, including Amperex, CPI, Draloric, Eimac, General Electric, Hitachi, Jennings, Litton, L3, National, NJRC, and Thales.
355948_11_ITEM15_P10_S0	Canvys Canvys is a global provider of integrated display products, workstations, and value-add services to the financial, corporate enterprise, healthcare, industrial and OEM markets.
355948_11_ITEM15_P10_S1	Our engineers design, manufacture, source, and support a full spectrum of solutions to match the needs of our customers.
355948_11_ITEM15_P10_S2	We offer custom display solutions that include touch screens, protective panels, custom enclosures, specialized cabinet finishes, and application specific software packages.
355948_11_ITEM15_P10_S3	We also offer display products under our own brands, including Image Systems and Pixelink.
355948_11_ITEM15_P10_S4	In addition, we partner with leading branded hardware vendors to offer the highest quality liquid crystal displays, mounting devices, and customized computing platforms.
355948_11_ITEM15_P11_S0	As a longtime provider of healthcare solutions, we specialize in creating comprehensive solutions for diagnostic and clinical review, 3-D and post processing, surgical suites and modality-specific applications.
355948_11_ITEM15_P11_S1	In addition, all of our solutions meet certifications and calibration standards for patient monitoring, bio-medical displays, ultrasound, cardiac imaging, picture archiving, and communication systems.
355948_11_ITEM15_P11_S2	We have long-standing relationships with key component and finished goods manufacturers including 3M, HP, IBM, Intel, LG, NEC Displays, Sharp Electronics, Samsung, and WIDE Corporation.
355948_11_ITEM15_P11_S3	We believe our distributor relationships, combined with our manufacturing capabilities and private label brands, allow us to maintain a well-balanced and technologically advanced line of products.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S0	Products and Suppliers Our inventory levels reflect our commitment to maintain an inventory of a broad range of products for customers who are buying product for replacement of components used in critical product equipment.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S1	In many cases, the market for our products is characterized by rapid change and obsolescence as a result of the introduction of new technologies.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S2	As of May 28, 2011, on average, we hold 72 days of inventory in the normal course of operations.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S3	This level of inventory reflects the fact that we also sell a number of products representing trailing edge technology.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S4	While the market for these trailing edge technology products is declining, we are increasing our market share.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S5	As manufacturers for these products exit the business, we often purchase a substantial portion of their remaining inventory.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S6	We have distribution agreements with many of our suppliers; however, a number of these agreements provide for nonexclusive distribution rights and often include territorial restrictions that limit the countries in which we can distribute their products.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S7	The agreements are generally short-term, subject to periodic renewal, and some contain provisions permitting termination by either party, without cause, upon relatively short notice.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S8	Although some of these agreements allow us to return inventory periodically, others do not, in which case we may have obsolete inventory that we cannot return to the supplier.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S9	Our suppliers generally warrant the products we distribute and allow return of defective products, including those returned to us by our customers.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S10	Except for certain displays, we generally do not provide additional warranties on the products we sell.
355948_11_ITEM15_P12_S11	For information regarding the warranty reserves, see Note 3 Significant Accounting Policies of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
355948_11_ITEM15_P13_S0	In addition to third party products, we sell proprietary products principally under certain trade names we own including: Amperex , Cetron , Image Systems , Pixelink , and National .
355948_11_ITEM15_P13_S1	Our proprietary products include thyratrons and rectifiers, power tubes, ignitrons, magnetron tubes, phototubes, microwave generators, large screen display monitors, liquid crystal display monitors, and computer workstations.
355948_11_ITEM15_P13_S2	The materials used in the manufacturing process consist of glass bulbs and tubing, nickel, stainless steel and other metals, plastic and metal bases, ceramics, and a wide variety of fabricated metal components.
355948_11_ITEM15_P13_S3	These materials are generally readily available, but some components may require long lead times for production, and some materials are subject to shortages or price fluctuations based on supply and demand.

355948_11_ITEM15_P14_S5	Customers can access our product inventory on our web site, www.rell.com , through electronic data interchange, or by telephone.
355948_11_ITEM15_P14_S6	Customer orders are processed by our regional sales offices and supported primarily by one of our distribution facilities in LaFox, Illinois; Amsterdam, Netherlands; Marlborough, Massachusetts; Plymouth, Minnesota; or Donaueschingen, Germany.
355948_11_ITEM15_P14_S7	Our data processing network provides on-line, real-time interconnection of all sales offices and central distribution operations, 24 hours per day, seven days per week.
355948_11_ITEM15_P14_S8	Information on stock availability, cross-reference information, customers, and market analyses are obtainable throughout the entire distribution network.

355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	should consider carefully the following risk factors in addition to the other information included and incorporated by reference in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. While we believe we have identified the key risk factors affecting our business, there may be additional risks and uncertainties that are not presently known or that are not currently believed to be significant that may adversely affect our results of operations.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	We intend to grow our sales and reduce costs to improve our profitability.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Our fixed costs are high relative to the size of our operations.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Since the sale of the RFPD division in March 2011, we have focused on re-aligning our cost structure to fit our remaining businesses.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S4	We have significantly reduced our expenses during Fiscal 2012; and therefore, further expense reduction opportunities may be limited.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S5	In addition, cost reduction objectives could have the effect of reducing our talent pool and available resources whether or not achieved, and, consequently, could affect our ability to serve customers and to hire and retain key personnel.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S6	Our long-term objective is to double the size of our business over the next three to five years through acquisitions and internal growth initiatives, which will allow us to leverage our support function cost structure.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P0_S7	To the extent we do not achieve our growth objectives, it will be difficult to reduce our fixed cost structure to align with the size of our operations We have historically incurred significant charges for inventory obsolescence, and may incur similar charges in the future.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We maintain significant inventories in an effort to ensure that customers have a reliable source of supply.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	The market for many of our products is characterized by rapid change resulting from the development of new technologies, evolving industry standards, frequent new product introductions by some of our customers and changing end-user demand, which can contribute to the decline in value or obsolescence of our inventory.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We do not have many long-term supply contracts with our customers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	If we fail to anticipate the changing needs of our customers or we fail to accurately forecast customer demand, our customers may not continue to place orders with us, and we may accumulate significant inventories of products which we will be unable to sell or return to our vendors.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P2_S2	This may result in a significant decline in the value of our inventory.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	We face competitive pressure in the markets we serve.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	We face many competitors, both global and local, in the markets we serve.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Not only do we compete with other distributors, we also compete for customers with many of our own suppliers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our overall competitive position depends on a number of factors including price, engineering capability, vendor representation, product diversity, lead times and the level of customer service.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Our competition includes hundreds of electronic component distributors of various sizes, locations, and market focuses, as well as original equipment manufacturers and refurbishers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Some of our competitors have greater resources and broader name recognition than we do.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S6	As a result, these competitors may be able to better withstand changing conditions within our markets and throughout the economy as a whole.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P3_S7	Increased competition may result in price reductions, reduced margins, or a loss of market share, any of which could materially and adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	EDG is dependent on a limited number of vendors to supply it with essential products.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	EDG s principal product is vacuum tubes.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	These tubes and certain other products supplied by EDG are currently produced by a relatively small number of manufacturers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	One of EDG s suppliers represents 18% of our total sales volume.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P5_S3	Our success depends, in large part, on maintaining current vendor relationships and developing new relationships.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P5_S4	We believe that some vendors supplying products to EDG product lines are consolidating their distribution relationships as a result of the declining market for vacuum tubes.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P5_S5	To the extent that our significant suppliers reduce the volume of product they sell through distribution and are unwilling to continue to do business with us, or extend lead times, or limiting supplies due to capacity constraints, or other factors, there could be a material adverse effect on our business.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Economic, political, and other risks associated with international sales and operations could adversely affect our results of operations.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Because we sell and source our products worldwide, our business is subject to risks associated with doing business internationally.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P7_S1	We anticipate that revenue from international operations will continue to represent a majority of our total revenue.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P7_S2	In addition, many of our employees, suppliers, and warehouse facilities are located outside the United States.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Accordingly, our future results could be harmed by a variety of factors including:
355948_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	geopolitical turmoil, including terrorism, war, or natural disasters, may negatively affect our results from operations Our products may be found to be defective or our services performed may result in equipment or product damage and, as a result, warranty and/or product liability claims may be asserted against us.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We sell many of our components at prices that are significantly lower than the cost of the equipment or other goods in which they are incorporated.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P9_S1	Additionally, we offer installation and repair services in conjunction with the selling of our components.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P9_S2	Since a defect or failure in a product or service could give rise to failures in the end products that incorporate them, we may face claims for damages that are disproportionate to the revenues and profits we receive from the components involved in the claims.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P9_S3	While we typically have provisions in our agreements with our suppliers that hold the supplier accountable for defective products, and we and our suppliers generally exclude consequential damages in our standard terms and conditions, our ability to avoid such liabilities may be limited as a result of various factors, including the inability to exclude such damages due to the laws of some of the countries where we do business.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Our business could be materially adversely affected as a result of a significant quality or performance issue in the components sold by us if we are required to pay for the damages that result.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Although we have product liability insurance, such insurance is limited in coverage and amount.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	A single stockholder has voting control over us.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P11_S1	As of July 22, 2012, Edward J. Richardson, our Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President, beneficially owned approximately 99% of the outstanding shares of our Class B common stock, representing approximately 69% of the voting power of the outstanding common stock.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P11_S2	This share ownership permits Mr. Richardson to exert control over the outcome of most stockholder votes, including votes concerning the election of directors, by-law amendments, possible mergers, corporate control contests, and other significant corporate transactions.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Our non-U.S. sales represent a significant portion of our revenues, and consequently, we are exposed to risks associated with operating internationally.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Because a significant portion of our business is conducted outside the U.S., we face exposure to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, which may harm our results of operations.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Price increases caused by currency exchange rate fluctuations may make our products less competitive or have an adverse effect on our margins.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Our international revenues and expenses generally are derived from sales and operations in currencies other than the U.S. dollar.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Accordingly, when the U.S. dollar strengthens in relation to the currencies of the countries in which we sell our products, our U.S. dollar reported net revenue and income will decrease.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P13_S2	We currently do not engage in any currency hedging transactions.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P13_S3	We cannot predict whether foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries will have a material adverse effect on our operations and financial results in the future.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Substantial defaults by our customers on our accounts receivable or the loss of significant customers could have a significant negative impact on our business.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	A significant portion of our working capital consists of accounts receivable from customers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P15_S1	If customers with a significant accounts receivable balance were to become insolvent or otherwise unable to pay for products and services, or were to become unwilling or unable to make payments in a timely manner, our business, results of operations, financial condition, or liquidity could be adversely affected.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P15_S2	Future acquisitions are subject to integration risks and other risks.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P16_S0	As part of our growth strategy, we intend to acquire additional businesses or assets.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Acquisitions are accompanied by risks, such as potential exposure to unknown liabilities of acquired companies and the possible loss of key employees and customers of the acquired business.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P16_S2	In addition, we may not obtain the expected benefits or cost savings from acquisitions.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Acquisitions are subject to risks associated with financing the acquisition and integrating the operations and personnel of the acquired businesses or assets.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P17_S1	If any of these risks materialize, they may result in disruptions to our business and the diversion of management time and attention, which could increase the costs of operating our existing or acquired businesses or negate the expected benefits of the acquisitions.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P17_S2	If we fail to maintain an effective system of internal controls or discover material weaknesses in our internal controls over financial reporting, we may not be able to detect fraud or report our financial results accurately or timely.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P17_S3	An effective internal control environment is necessary for us to produce reliable financial reports and is an important part of our effort to prevent financial fraud.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P17_S4	We are required to periodically evaluate the effectiveness of the design and operation of our internal controls over financial reporting.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P17_S5	Based on these evaluations, we may conclude that enhancements, modifications or changes to internal controls are necessary or desirable.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S0	While management evaluates the effectiveness of our internal controls on a regular basis, these controls may not always be effective.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S1	There are inherent limitations on the effectiveness of internal controls, including fraud, collusion, management override, and failure in human judgment.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S2	In addition, control procedures are designed to reduce rather than eliminate business risks.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S3	If we fail to maintain an effective system of internal controls, or if management or our independent registered public accounting firm discovers material weaknesses in our internal controls, we may be unable to produce reliable financial reports or prevent fraud.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S4	In addition, we may be subject to sanctions or investigation by regulatory authorities, such as the Securities and Exchange Commission or NASDAQ Global Select Market.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Any such actions could result in an adverse reaction in the financial markets due to a loss of confidence in the reliability of our financial statements.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P18_S6	We may be subject to intellectual property rights claims, which are costly to defend, could require payment of damages or licensing fees, and could limit our ability to use certain technologies in the future.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Substantial litigation and threats of litigation regarding intellectual property rights exist in the display systems and electronics industries.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P20_S0	From time to time, third parties (including certain companies in the business of acquiring patents not for the purpose of developing technology but with the intention of aggressively seeking licensing revenue from purported infringers) may assert patent and/or other intellectual property rights to technologies that are important to our business.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P20_S1	In any dispute involving products that we have sold, our customers could also become the target of litigation.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P20_S2	We are obligated in many instances to indemnify and defend our customers if the products we sell are alleged to infringe any third party s intellectual property rights.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P20_S3	In some cases, depending on the nature of the claim, we may be able to seek indemnification from our suppliers for our self and our customers against such claims, but there is no assurance that we will be successful in obtaining such indemnification or that we are fully protected against such claims.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P20_S4	Any infringement claim brought against us, regardless of the duration, outcome or size of damage award, could:
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S0	require us to seek to enter into royalty or other licensing agreements.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Additionally, if an infringement claim is successful we may be required to pay damages or seek royalty or license arrangements, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S2	The payment of any such damages or royalties may significantly increase our operating expenses and harm our operating results and financial condition.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S3	Also, royalty or license arrangements may not be available at all.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S4	We may have to stop selling certain products or using technologies, which could affect our ability to compete effectively.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Potential lawsuits, with or without merit, may divert our management s attention, and we may incur significant expenses in our defense.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S6	In addition, we may be required to pay damage awards or settlements, become subject to injunctions or other equitable remedies, or determine to abandon certain lines of business, that may cause a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position, and cash flows.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S7	We depend on key management and employees, the loss of whom may prevent us from implementing our business plans, limit our profitability and decrease the value of our common stock.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S8	We are dependent on the talent and resources of our key executives and employees.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S9	In particular, the success of our business depends to a great extent on Edward J. Richardson, our President, Chief Executive Officer and the Chairman of our Board of Directors.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S10	Mr. Richardson has extensive experience in the electron device industry, and his services are critical to our success.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S11	We have not obtained key man insurance with respect to Mr. Richardson or any of our executive officers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P21_S12	The loss of Mr. Richardson may prevent us from implementing our business plan, which may limit our profitability and decrease the value of our common stock.

355948_12_ITEM1A_P22_S0	As a result of the closing of the Transaction, we have significant cash reserves.

355948_12_ITEM1A_P25_S1	If we are deemed to be subject to the Investment Company Act, compliance with these additional regulatory burdens would increase our operating expenses.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P26_S0	As a global company, we rely heavily on information technology systems, which, if not properly functioning, could materially adversely affect our business.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We rely on these information systems to process, analyze, and manage data to facilitate the purchase and distribution of our products, as well as to receive, process, bill, and ship orders on a timely basis.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P27_S1	If the IT services provided by Arrow Electronics are not provided to us in an adequate manner, we may be unable to find an alternative means of obtaining such IT services, which could significantly impair our ability to effectively serve our customers and perform other vital company functions.

355948_12_ITEM1A_P27_S4	To the extent we cannot timely complete this project, our business may suffer and we may incur significant additional costs.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P27_S5	Economic weakness and uncertainty could adversely affect our revenues and gross margins.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Our revenues and gross profit margins depend significantly on worldwide economic conditions, the demand for our products and services and the financial condition of our customers.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Economic weakness and uncertainty have in the past resulted, and may result in the future, in decreased revenues and gross profit margins.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Economic weakness and uncertainty also make it more difficult for us to forecast overall supply and demand with a great deal of confidence.
355948_12_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Our operating results during Fiscal 2012 show that the business has experienced a decline in sales volume, and there can be no assurance that we will experience a recovery in the near future; nor can there be any assurance that such worldwide economic volatility experienced recently will not continue.
