355948_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value displays, flat panel detector solutions and replacement parts for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_16_ITEM7_P4_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_16_ITEM7_P4_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	On June 15, 2015, Richardson Electronics, Ltd ( the Company ), acquired certain assets of International Medical Equipment and Services, Inc. ( IMES ), for a purchase price of $12.2 million.
355948_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	This includes the purchase of inventory, receivables, fixed assets, and certain other assets of the Company.
355948_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	The Company did not acquire any liabilities of IMES.
355948_16_ITEM7_P6_S3	The total consideration paid excludes transaction costs.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	IMES, based in South Carolina, provides reliable, cost-saving solutions worldwide for major brands of CT and MRI equipment.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	This acquisition positions Richardson Healthcare to provide cost effective diagnostic imaging replacement parts and training to hospitals, diagnostic imaging centers, medical institutions, and independent service organizations.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	IMES offers an extensive selection of replacement parts, as well as an interactive training center, on-site test bays and experienced technicians who provide 24/7 customer support.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	Replacement parts are readily available and triple tested to provide peace of mind when uptime is critical.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S4	IMES core operations will remain in South Carolina.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S5	Richardson Healthcare plans to expand IMES replacement parts and training offerings geographically leveraging the Company s global infrastructure.
355948_16_ITEM7_P7_S6	During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, IMES opened up their first foreign location in Amsterdam.
355948_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ), launched in July 2015, combines Electron Device Group s ( EDG ) core engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tube business with new RF and power technologies.
355948_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	As a manufacturer and authorized distributor, PMT s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_16_ITEM7_P9_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair all through our existing global infrastructure.
355948_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	PMT s focus is on products for power, RF and microwave applications for customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial, and medical original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ) markets.
355948_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Healthcare manufactures, distributes and services high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	Products include power grid tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; Image Systems medical displays and workstations for picture archiving and communication systems ( PACS ); visual solutions for operating rooms/surgical environments; digital radiography solutions including replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe, and Latin America.

355948_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ) requires management to make significant estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
355948_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	Management continuously evaluates its critical accounting policies and estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, revenue recognition, inventory obsolescence, goodwill and other intangible assets, loss contingencies, and income taxes.
355948_16_ITEM7_P74_S2	Management bases the estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, however, actual results could differ from those estimates.
355948_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	The policies discussed below are considered by management to be critical to understanding our financial position and the results of operations.
355948_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	Their application involves significant judgments and estimates in preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM7_P75_S2	For all of these policies, management cautions that future events rarely develop exactly as forecasted, and the best estimates routinely require adjustment.
355948_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	Our allowance for doubtful accounts includes estimated losses that result from uncollectible receivables.
355948_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	The estimates are influenced by the following: continuing credit evaluation of customers financial conditions; aging of receivables, individually and in the aggregate; a large number of customers which are widely dispersed across geographic areas; collectability and delinquency history by geographic area; and the fact that no single customer accounts for more than 10% of net sales.
355948_16_ITEM7_P76_S2	Significant changes in one or more of these considerations may require adjustments affecting net income and net carrying value of accounts receivable.
355948_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts was approximately $0.4 million as of May 28, 2016, and $0.3 million as of May 30, 2015.
355948_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	Our product sales are recognized as revenue upon shipment, when title passes to the customer, when delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, and when collectability is reasonably assured.
355948_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	We also record estimated discounts and returns based on our historical experience.
355948_16_ITEM7_P78_S2	Our products are often manufactured to meet the specific design needs of our customers applications.
355948_16_ITEM7_P78_S3	Our engineers work closely with customers to ensure that our products will meet their needs.
355948_16_ITEM7_P78_S4	Our customers are under no obligation to compensate us for designing the products we sell.
355948_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	Our worldwide inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market, generally using a weighted-average cost method.
355948_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	Our inventories included approximately $40.0 million of finished goods, $4.4 million of raw materials, and $1.0 million of work-in-progress as of May 28, 2016, as compared to approximately $33.7 million of finished goods, $3.2 million of raw materials, and $1.9 million of work-in-progress as of May 30, 2015.
355948_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	Provisions for obsolete or slow moving inventories are recorded based upon regular analysis of stock rotation privileges, obsolescence, the exiting of certain market segments, and assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
355948_16_ITEM7_P80_S1	If future demand, changes in the industry, or market conditions differ from management s estimates, additional provisions may be necessary.

355948_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	During the fourth quarter of each fiscal year, our goodwill balances are reviewed for impairment using the third quarter as the measurement date.
355948_16_ITEM7_P83_S1	If after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in ASU 2011-08 we determine that it is not likely that the fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, then we test for impairment through the application of a fair value based test.
355948_16_ITEM7_P83_S2	We estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units based on projected future operating results, market approach, and discounted cash flows.
355948_16_ITEM7_P83_S3	Projected future operating results and cash flows used for valuation purposes may reflect considerable improvements relative to historical periods with respect to, among other things, revenue growth and operating margins.
355948_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	Although we believe our projected future operating results and cash flows and related estimates regarding fair values are based on reasonable assumptions, historically, projected operating results and cash flows have not always been achieved.
355948_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	In accordance with ASC 350 Intangibles - Goodwill and Other , if indicators of impairment are deemed to be present, we would perform an interim impairment test and any resulting impairment loss would be charged to expense in the period identified.
355948_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	Our goodwill impairment testing follows the two-step process as defined in ASC 350.
355948_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	The first step in the process compares the fair value of the reporting unit to its carrying value.
355948_16_ITEM7_P87_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recognized.
355948_16_ITEM7_P87_S2	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit resulting from the first step of the evaluation is allocated to the fair value of all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit in order to determine an implied goodwill value.
355948_16_ITEM7_P87_S3	This allocation is similar to the purchase price allocation performed in purchase accounting.
355948_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	If the carrying amount of the goodwill reported exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss should be recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
355948_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	Intangible assets are initially recorded at their fair market values determined on quoted market prices in active markets, if available, or recognized valuation models.
355948_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized on a straight-line basis over their useful lives.
355948_16_ITEM7_P89_S2	Our intangible assets represent the fair value for trade name, customer relationships, non-compete agreements, and technology acquired in connection with the acquisitions.
355948_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	We review property and equipment, definite-lived intangible assets, and other long-lived assets for impairment whenever adverse events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amounts of such assets may not be recoverable.
355948_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	We accrue a liability for loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
355948_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	When only a range of possible losses can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_16_ITEM7_P91_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	We recognize deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the differences between financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of assets and liabilities.
355948_16_ITEM7_P93_S1	We regularly review our deferred tax assets for recoverability and determine the need for a valuation allowance based on a number of factors, including both positive and negative evidence.
355948_16_ITEM7_P93_S2	These factors include historical taxable income or loss, projected future taxable income or loss, the expected timing of the reversals of existing temporary differences, and the implementation of tax planning strategies.
355948_16_ITEM7_P93_S3	In circumstances where we, or any of our affiliates, have incurred three years of cumulative losses which constitute significant negative evidence, positive evidence of equal or greater significance is needed to overcome the negative evidence before a tax benefit is recognized for deductible temporary differences and loss carryforwards.
355948_16_ITEM7_P93_S4	See Note 9 Income Taxes of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further information.
355948_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606).
355948_16_ITEM7_P94_S1	ASU 2014-09 is principles based guidance that can be applied to all contracts with customers, enhancing comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions and capital markets.
355948_16_ITEM7_P95_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that entities should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services.
355948_16_ITEM7_P95_S1	The guidance details the steps entities should apply to achieve the core principle.
355948_16_ITEM7_P96_S0	For public entities, ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period; early adoption is not permitted.
355948_16_ITEM7_P96_S1	We are currently evaluating the impact that the adoption of ASU 2014-09 will have on our financial condition, results of operations and disclosures.
355948_16_ITEM7_P97_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, Leases.
355948_16_ITEM7_P97_S1	ASU 2016-02 establishes a right-of-use ( ROU ) model that requires a lessee to record a ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer than 12 months.
355948_16_ITEM7_P97_S2	Leases will be classified as either finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the income statement.
355948_16_ITEM7_P98_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
355948_16_ITEM7_P99_S0	A modified retrospective transition approach is required for lessees for capital and operating leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in the financial statements, with certain practical expedients available.
355948_16_ITEM7_P99_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of ASU 2016-02 on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM7_P100_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
355948_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	ASU 2015-11 requires inventory within the scope of the ASU (e.g., first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) or average cost) to be measured using the lower of cost and net realizable value.
355948_16_ITEM7_P100_S2	Inventory excluded from the scope of the ASU (i.e., last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) or the retail inventory method) will continue to be measured at the lower of cost or market.
355948_16_ITEM7_P100_S3	The ASU also amends some of the other guidance in Topic 330, Inventory, to more clearly articulate the requirements for the measurement and disclosure of inventory.
355948_16_ITEM7_P100_S4	However, those amendments are not intended to result in any changes to current practice.
355948_16_ITEM7_P101_S0	ASU 2015-11 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_16_ITEM7_P101_S1	The adoption of this standard is not expected to have a significant impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM7_P102_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17 , Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes , eliminating the current requirement for companies to present deferred tax assets and liabilities as current and noncurrent.
355948_16_ITEM7_P102_S1	Instead, companies will be required to classify all deferred tax assets and liabilities as noncurrent.
355948_16_ITEM7_P102_S2	This ASU is effective for annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2016, including interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_16_ITEM7_P102_S3	The adoption of this guidance will result in a balance sheet reclassification and require related disclosure revisions in the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM7_P103_S0	In March 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) 2016-09, Compensation Stock Compensation: Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting.
355948_16_ITEM7_P103_S1	ASU 2016-09 introduces targeted amendments intended to simplify the accounting for stock compensation.
355948_16_ITEM7_P103_S2	Specifically, the ASU requires all excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies (including tax benefits of dividends on share-based payment awards) to be recognized as income tax expense or benefit in the income statement.
355948_16_ITEM7_P104_S0	The tax effects of exercised or vested awards should be treated as discrete items in the reporting period in which they occur.
355948_16_ITEM7_P104_S1	An entity also should recognize excess tax benefits, and assess the need for a valuation allowance, regardless of whether the benefit reduces taxes payable in the current period.
355948_16_ITEM7_P104_S2	That is, off balance sheet accounting for net operating losses stemming from excess tax benefits would no longer be required and instead such net operating losses would be recognized when they arise.
355948_16_ITEM7_P104_S3	Existing net operating losses that are currently tracked off balance sheet would be recognized, net of a valuation allowance if required, through an adjustment to opening retained earnings in the period of adoption.
355948_16_ITEM7_P105_S0	Entities will no longer need to maintain and track an APIC pool.
355948_16_ITEM7_P105_S1	The ASU also requires excess tax benefits to be classified along with other income tax cash flows as an operating activity in the statement of cash flows.
355948_16_ITEM7_P106_S0	In addition, ASU 2016-09 elevates the statutory tax withholding threshold to qualify for equity classification up to the maximum statutory tax rates in the applicable jurisdiction(s).
355948_16_ITEM7_P106_S1	The ASU also clarifies that cash paid by an employer when directly withholding shares for tax withholding purposes should be classified as a financing activity.
355948_16_ITEM7_P107_S0	ASU 2016-09 provides an optional accounting policy election (with limited exceptions), to be applied on an entity-wide basis, to either estimate the number of awards that are expected to vest (consistent with existing U.S. GAAP) or account for forfeitures when they occur.
355948_16_ITEM7_P107_S1	ASU 2016-09 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_16_ITEM7_P107_S2	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of this standard on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value displays, flat panel detector solutions and replacement parts for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_16_ITEM8_P0_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P0_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_16_ITEM8_P0_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_16_ITEM8_P1_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	During the first quarter of fiscal 2015, we created a new strategic business unit called Richardson Healthcare ( Healthcare ).
355948_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	Healthcare was previously included in our Canvys business unit.
355948_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	As hospitals remain under pressure to reduce costs while serving a much larger customer base, there is a growing demand for independent sources of high-value replacement parts for diagnostic imaging.
355948_16_ITEM8_P3_S1	Having access to parts that are tested and in stock enables hospitals to terminate expensive service contracts with the Original Equipment Manufacturers ( OEM ) and instead use third party service providers or in-house technicians.
355948_16_ITEM8_P3_S2	With our global infrastructure, technical sales team, and experience servicing the healthcare market, we are well positioned to take advantage of this market opportunity.
355948_16_ITEM8_P3_S3	Over time, our plan is to expand our position from being the leader in power grid tubes to a key player in the high-growth, high-profile healthcare industry.
355948_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	Electron Device Group ( EDG ), renamed Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ) in July 2015, provides engineered solutions and distributes electronic components to customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P5_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_16_ITEM8_P5_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, industrial, and OEM markets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	Healthcare manufactures, distributes and services high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_16_ITEM8_P7_S1	Products include power grid tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; Image Systems medical displays and workstations for picture archiving and communication systems ( PACS ); visual solutions for operating rooms/surgical environments; digital radiography solutions including replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_16_ITEM8_P9_S0	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe, and Latin America.
355948_16_ITEM8_P10_S0	One customer represented $3.8 million, or 15%, of our total accounts receivable balance, as of May 28, 2016.
355948_16_ITEM8_P10_S1	This receivable was collected in the first month of our fiscal year 2017.
355948_16_ITEM8_P10_S2	For the fiscal year ended May 30, 2015, the Company did not have any specific customer receivable balance that exceeded 10% of our total accounts receivable.

355948_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	Use of Estimates: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make significant estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
355948_16_ITEM8_P15_S1	Management continuously evaluates its critical accounting policies and estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, revenue recognition, inventory obsolescence, goodwill and other intangible assets, loss contingencies, and income taxes.
355948_16_ITEM8_P15_S2	Management bases the estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, however, actual results could differ from those estimates.

355948_16_ITEM8_P16_S1	Our financial instruments include investments, accounts receivable, accounts payable, and accrued liabilities.
355948_16_ITEM8_P16_S2	The fair values of these financial instruments approximate carrying values at May 28, 2016, and May 30, 2015.
355948_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents: We consider short-term, highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash, and so near their maturity that they present insignificant risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates, and that have a maturity of three months or less, when purchased, to be cash equivalents.
355948_16_ITEM8_P17_S1	The carrying amounts reported in the balance sheet for cash and cash equivalents approximate the fair market value of these assets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: Our allowance for doubtful accounts includes estimated losses that result from uncollectible receivables.
355948_16_ITEM8_P18_S1	The estimates are influenced by the following: continuing credit evaluation of customers financial conditions; aging of receivables, individually and in the aggregate; a large number of customers which are widely dispersed across geographic areas; collectability and delinquency history by geographic area; and the fact that no single customer accounts for more than 10% of net sales.
355948_16_ITEM8_P18_S2	Significant changes in one or more of these considerations may require adjustments affecting net income and net carrying value of accounts receivable.

355948_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	Loss Contingencies: We accrue a liability for loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
355948_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	When only a range of possible loss can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_16_ITEM8_P20_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	Our product sales are recognized as revenue upon shipment, when title passes to the customer, when delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, and when collectability is reasonably assured.
355948_16_ITEM8_P22_S1	We also record estimated discounts and returns based on our historical experience.
355948_16_ITEM8_P22_S2	Our products are often manufactured to meet the specific design needs of our customers applications.
355948_16_ITEM8_P22_S3	Our engineers work closely with customers to ensure that our products will meet their needs.
355948_16_ITEM8_P22_S4	Our customers are under no obligation to compensate us for designing the products we sell.

355948_16_ITEM8_P23_S2	Revenues and expenses are translated at the current rate on the date of the transaction.

355948_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets: We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicates an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	During the fourth quarter of each fiscal year, our goodwill balances are reviewed for impairment using the third quarter as the measurement date.
355948_16_ITEM8_P34_S1	If after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in ASU 2011-08 we determine that it is not likely that the fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, then we test for impairment through the application of a fair value based test.
355948_16_ITEM8_P34_S2	We estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units based on projected future operating results, market approach, and discounted cash flows.
355948_16_ITEM8_P34_S3	Projected future operating results and cash flows used for valuation purposes may reflect considerable improvements relative to historical periods with respect to, among other things, revenue growth and operating margins.
355948_16_ITEM8_P35_S0	Although we believe our projected future operating results and cash flows and related estimates regarding fair values are based on reasonable assumptions, historically, projected operating results and cash flows have not always been achieved.
355948_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	In accordance with ASC 350 Intangibles - Goodwill and Other , if indicators of impairment are deemed to be present, we would perform an interim impairment test and any resulting impairment loss would be charged to expense in the period identified.
355948_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	For annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011, Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2011-08, Testing for Goodwill for Impairment ( ASU 2011-08 ) permits an entity to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events or circumstances leads to a determination that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount.
355948_16_ITEM8_P37_S1	If, after assessing the totality of events or circumstances, an entity determines it is not likely that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then performing the two-step impairment test is unnecessary.
355948_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	Intangible assets are initially recorded at their fair market values determined on quoted market prices in active markets, if available, or recognized valuation models.
355948_16_ITEM8_P38_S1	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized over their useful lives and are tested when events or changes in circumstances occur that indicate possible impairment.

355948_16_ITEM8_P57_S2	We intend to continue to utilize the Simplified Method for future grants in accordance with SAB No. 110 until such time that we believe that our historical stock option experience will provide a reasonable basis to estimate an expected term.

355948_16_ITEM8_P62_S2	With respect to dividends and distributions, shares of common stock and Class B common stock rank equally and have the same rights, except that Class B common stock cash dividends are limited to 90% of the amount of Class A common stock cash dividends.
355948_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	In accordance with ASC 260-10, Earnings Per Share ( ASC 260 ), our Class B common stock is considered a participating security requiring the use of the two-class method for the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share.
355948_16_ITEM8_P63_S1	The two-class computation method for each period reflects the cash dividends paid per share for each class of stock, plus the amount of allocated undistributed earnings per share computed using the participation percentage which reflects the dividend rights of each class of stock.
355948_16_ITEM8_P63_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were computed using the two-class method as prescribed in ASC 260.
355948_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	The shares of Class B common stock are considered to be participating convertible securities since the shares of Class B common stock are convertible on a share-for-share basis into shares of common stock and may participate in dividends with common stock according to a predetermined formula which is 90% of the amount of Class A common stock cash dividends.

355948_16_ITEM8_P67_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606).
355948_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	ASU 2014-09 is principles based guidance that can be applied to all contracts with customers, enhancing comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions and capital markets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P68_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that entities should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services.
355948_16_ITEM8_P68_S1	The guidance details the steps entities should apply to achieve the core principle.
355948_16_ITEM8_P69_S0	For public entities, ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period; early adoption is not permitted.
355948_16_ITEM8_P69_S1	We are currently evaluating the impact that the adoption of ASU 2014-09 will have on our financial condition, results of operations and disclosures.
355948_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, Leases.
355948_16_ITEM8_P70_S1	ASU 2016-02 establishes a right-of-use ( ROU ) model that requires a lessee to record a ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer than 12 months.
355948_16_ITEM8_P70_S2	Leases will be classified as either finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the income statement.
355948_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
355948_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	A modified retrospective transition approach is required for lessees for capital and operating leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in the financial statements, with certain practical expedients available.
355948_16_ITEM8_P72_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of ASU 2016-02 on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
355948_16_ITEM8_P73_S1	ASU 2015-11 requires inventory within the scope of the ASU (e.g., first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) or average cost) to be measured using the lower of cost and net realizable value.
355948_16_ITEM8_P73_S2	Inventory excluded from the scope of the ASU (i.e., last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) or the retail inventory method) will continue to be measured at the lower of cost or market.
355948_16_ITEM8_P73_S3	The ASU also amends some of the other guidance in Topic 330, Inventory, to more clearly articulate the requirements for the measurement and disclosure of inventory.
355948_16_ITEM8_P73_S4	However, those amendments are not intended to result in any changes to current practice.
355948_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	ASU 2015-11 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_16_ITEM8_P74_S1	The adoption of this standard is not expected to have a significant impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P75_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17 , Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes , eliminating the current requirement for companies to present deferred tax assets and liabilities as current and noncurrent.
355948_16_ITEM8_P75_S1	Instead, companies will be required to classify all deferred tax assets and liabilities as noncurrent.
355948_16_ITEM8_P75_S2	This ASU is effective for annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2016, including interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_16_ITEM8_P75_S3	The adoption of this guidance will result in a balance sheet reclassification and require related disclosure revisions in the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P76_S0	In March 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) 2016-09, Compensation Stock Compensation: Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting.
355948_16_ITEM8_P76_S1	ASU 2016-09 introduces targeted amendments intended to simplify the accounting for stock compensation.
355948_16_ITEM8_P76_S2	Specifically, the ASU requires all excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies (including tax benefits of dividends on share-based payment awards) to be recognized as income tax expense or benefit in the income statement.
355948_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	The tax effects of exercised or vested awards should be treated as discrete items in the reporting period in which they occur.
355948_16_ITEM8_P77_S1	An entity also should recognize excess tax benefits, and assess the need for a valuation allowance, regardless of whether the benefit reduces taxes payable in the current period.
355948_16_ITEM8_P77_S2	That is, off balance sheet accounting for net operating losses stemming from excess tax benefits would no longer be required and instead such net operating losses would be recognized when they arise.
355948_16_ITEM8_P77_S3	Existing net operating losses that are currently tracked off balance sheet would be recognized, net of a valuation allowance if required, through an adjustment to opening retained earnings in the period of adoption.
355948_16_ITEM8_P78_S0	Entities will no longer need to maintain and track an APIC pool.
355948_16_ITEM8_P78_S1	The ASU also requires excess tax benefits to be classified along with other income tax cash flows as an operating activity in the statement of cash flows.
355948_16_ITEM8_P79_S0	In addition, ASU 2016-09 elevates the statutory tax withholding threshold to qualify for equity classification up to the maximum statutory tax rates in the applicable jurisdiction(s).
355948_16_ITEM8_P79_S1	The ASU also clarifies that cash paid by an employer when directly withholding shares for tax withholding purposes should be classified as a financing activity.
355948_16_ITEM8_P80_S0	ASU 2016-09 provides an optional accounting policy election (with limited exceptions), to be applied on an entity-wide basis, to either estimate the number of awards that are expected to vest (consistent with existing U.S. GAAP) or account for forfeitures when they occur.
355948_16_ITEM8_P80_S1	ASU 2016-09 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_16_ITEM8_P80_S2	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of this standard on the Company s consolidated financial statements.

355948_16_ITEM8_P131_S0	Employee Profit Sharing Plan: The employee profit sharing plan is a defined contribution profit sharing plan for employees.

355948_16_ITEM8_P132_S0	During the first quarter of fiscal 2015, we created a new strategic business unit called Healthcare.
355948_16_ITEM8_P133_S0	As hospitals remain under pressure to reduce costs while serving a much larger customer base, there is a growing demand for independent sources of high value replacement parts for diagnostic imaging.
355948_16_ITEM8_P133_S1	Having access to parts that are tested and in stock enables hospitals to terminate expensive service contracts with OEM and instead use third party service providers or in-house technicians.
355948_16_ITEM8_P133_S2	With our global infrastructure, technical sales team, and experience servicing the healthcare market, we are well positioned to take advantage of this market opportunity.
355948_16_ITEM8_P133_S3	Over time, our plan is to expand our position from being the leader in power grid tubes to a key player in the high-growth, high-profile Healthcare industry.
355948_16_ITEM8_P134_S0	In accordance with ASC 280-10, Segment Reporting , we have identified three reportable segments: PMT and Canvys, and Healthcare.
355948_16_ITEM8_P135_S0	Electron Device Group ( EDG ), renamed Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ) in July 2015, provides engineered solutions and distributes electronic components to customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P135_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_16_ITEM8_P135_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_16_ITEM8_P136_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, industrial, and OEM markets.
355948_16_ITEM8_P137_S0	Healthcare manufactures, distributes and services high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_16_ITEM8_P137_S1	Products include power grid tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; Image Systems medical displays and workstations for picture archiving and communication systems ( PACS ); visual solutions for operating rooms/surgical environments; digital radiography solutions including replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_16_ITEM8_P138_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_16_ITEM8_P139_S0	The CEO evaluates performance and allocates resources primarily based on the gross profit of each segment.

355948_16_ITEM8_P154_S0	ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures ( ASC 820 ), defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P155_S0	ASC 820 establishes a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
355948_16_ITEM8_P155_S1	These tiers include: Level 1, defined as observable inputs such as quoted prices in active markets; Level 2, defined as inputs other than quoted prices in active markets that are either directly or indirectly observable; and Level 3, defined as unobservable inputs in which little or no market data exists; therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions.
355948_16_ITEM8_P156_S0	As of May 28, 2016, we held investments that are required to be measured at fair value on a recurring basis.
355948_16_ITEM8_P156_S1	Our investments consist of time deposits and CDs, where face value is equal to fair value, and equity securities of publicly traded companies for which market prices are readily available.

355948_16_ITEM8_P171_S1	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Item 9A, Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting .

355948_16_ITEM8_P172_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).

355948_16_ITEM8_P172_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
355948_16_ITEM8_P172_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
355948_16_ITEM8_P173_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
355948_16_ITEM8_P173_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P174_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
355948_16_ITEM8_P174_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
355948_16_ITEM8_P175_S0	In our opinion, Richardson Electronics, Ltd. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of May 28, 2016, based on the COSO criteria .
355948_16_ITEM8_P176_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Richardson Electronics, Ltd. as of May 28, 2016 and May 30, 2015 and the related consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss), stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the two years in the period ended May 28, 2016 and our report dated July 29, 2016 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon .

355948_16_ITEM15_P50_S0	LaFox, IL, July 20, 2016: Richardson Electronics, Ltd. (NASDAQ: RELL) today reported financial results for its fourth quarter and fiscal year ended May 28, 2016.
355948_16_ITEM15_P50_S1	The Company also announced that its Board of Directors declared a $0.06 per share quarterly cash dividend.
355948_16_ITEM15_P51_S0	Net sales for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 were $39.6 million, a 13.2% increase, compared to net sales of $35.0 million in the prior year.
355948_16_ITEM15_P51_S1	Sales increased $3.9 million for PMT and $1.6 million for Healthcare, which includes net sales for International Medical Equipment Systems ( IMES ), acquired early this fiscal year.
355948_16_ITEM15_P51_S2	The increase was partially offset by a $0.9 million decrease in Canvys.
355948_16_ITEM15_P52_S0	Gross margin increased to $13.4 million, or 33.8% of net sales during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, compared to $10.2 million, or 29.2% of net sales during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P52_S1	Margin improved as a percent of net sales primarily due to sales of diagnostic imaging replacement parts in the Healthcare business.
355948_16_ITEM15_P53_S0	Operating expenses increased to $13.7 million for fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, compared to $12.9 million for fourth quarter of fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P53_S1	However, operating expenses as a percent of net sales improved to 34.6% versus 36.8% in the same period last year.
355948_16_ITEM15_P53_S2	The increase in SG A was due to $1.1 million related to IMES and additional investments in our Richardson Healthcare business and $0.8 million in PMT, partially offset by decreases of $0.3 million in IT services, $0.6 million in our other support functions, and $0.2 million in Canvys.
355948_16_ITEM15_P54_S0	As a result, operating loss for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 was $0.3 million, compared to an operating loss of $2.6 million in the prior year s fourth quarter.
355948_16_ITEM15_P55_S0	Other expense for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, including foreign exchange, was less than $0.1 million, compared to less than $0.1 million in other income in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P56_S0	The income tax benefit of $0.2 million during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 reflects an adjusted lower provision for foreign taxes as well as the valuation allowance recorded against the net operating loss in the U.S.
355948_16_ITEM15_P57_S0	Net loss for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 was $0.2 million, compared to net loss of $2.2 million during the fourth quarter of last year.
355948_16_ITEM15_P58_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2016 were $142.0 million, a 3.7% increase, compared to net sales of $137.0 million in the prior year.
355948_16_ITEM15_P58_S1	Sales for the Company s Healthcare business increased $6.4 million, which includes net sales for IMES, acquired early this fiscal year.
355948_16_ITEM15_P58_S2	The increase was partially offset by a $1.2 million decrease in Canvys and $0.2 million decrease in PMT.
355948_16_ITEM15_P59_S0	Gross margin increased to $44.8 million, or 31.6% of net sales during fiscal 2016, compared to $41.1 million, or 30.0% of net sales during fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P59_S1	Margin improved as a percent of sales primarily due to higher margins associated with the sale of diagnostic imaging replacement parts in the Healthcare business.
355948_16_ITEM15_P60_S0	Operating expenses increased to $51.6 million for fiscal 2016, compared to $49.2 million for the fiscal 2015 and as a percentage of sales increased from 35.9% to 36.4%.
355948_16_ITEM15_P60_S1	The increase in SG A reflected $5.0 million for IMES and additional investments in our Richardson Healthcare business and $0.7 million in PMT, partially offset by decreases of $1.9 million in IT services, $0.9 million in our other support functions, and $0.5 million in Canvys.
355948_16_ITEM15_P61_S0	As a result, operating loss for fiscal 2016 was $6.6 million, compared to an operating loss of $8.1 million in fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P62_S0	Other income for fiscal 2016, including foreign exchange, was $0.3 million, compared to $1.1 million in other income for fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P63_S0	The income tax provision of $0.5 million during fiscal 2016 was due to foreign income tax expense and additional tax due in Germany that resulted from an audit.
355948_16_ITEM15_P64_S0	Net loss for fiscal 2016 was $6.8 million, compared to net loss of $5.6 million during fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P65_S0	The Company also announced today that its Board of Directors declared a $0.06 quarterly dividend per share to holders of common stock and a $0.054 cash dividend per share to holders of Class B common stock.
355948_16_ITEM15_P65_S1	The dividend will be payable on August 24, 2016, to common stockholders of record on August 8, 2016.
355948_16_ITEM15_P66_S0	Cash and investments at the end of the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 were $70.5 million.
355948_16_ITEM15_P66_S1	During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, the Company did not repurchase any shares of its common stock under the existing share repurchase authorization.
355948_16_ITEM15_P66_S2	Since the sale of RFPD, the Company has spent $65.6 million on share repurchases and currently has 10.7 million outstanding shares of common stock and 2.1 million outstanding shares of Class B common stock.
355948_16_ITEM15_P67_S0	Since the sale of RFPD in 2011, we have spent more than $17 million on dividends, said Edward J. Richardson, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President.
355948_16_ITEM15_P67_S1	Including share repurchases, we have returned more than $82 million to our shareholders.
355948_16_ITEM15_P67_S2	Our intent now is to further improve shareholder value by investing in our growth initiatives.
355948_16_ITEM15_P68_S0	We are pleased with the significant improvement in our financial performance in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016 as compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015.
355948_16_ITEM15_P68_S1	In addition to a large U.S. government sale, there were other areas of improvement, including strong IMES sales and gross margin and lower S, G A expenses as a percent of net sales, said Mr. Richardson.
355948_16_ITEM15_P69_S0	We are highly focused on revenue growth in fiscal 2017, while carefully managing our cash flow.
355948_16_ITEM15_P69_S1	We have implemented programs to reduce our run rate expenses for fiscal year 2017, and are working on more operational improvement initiatives so we may continue to invest in our growth strategy, Mr. Richardson concluded.

355948_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value flat panel detector solutions, replacement parts, tubes and service training for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM1_P0_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_17_ITEM1_P0_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	During the first quarter of fiscal 2015, we created a new strategic business unit called Richardson Healthcare ( Healthcare ).
355948_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	As hospitals remain under pressure to reduce costs while serving a much larger customer base, there is a growing demand for independent sources of high-value replacement parts for diagnostic imaging.
355948_17_ITEM1_P3_S1	Having access to parts that are tested and in stock enables hospitals to terminate expensive service contracts with the Original Equipment Manufacturers ( OEM ) and instead use third party service providers or in-house technicians.
355948_17_ITEM1_P3_S2	With our global infrastructure, technical sales team, and experience servicing the healthcare market, we are well positioned to take advantage of this market opportunity.
355948_17_ITEM1_P3_S3	Over time, our plan is to expand our position from being the leader in power grid tubes to a key player in the high-growth, high-profile healthcare industry.
355948_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our fiscal year 2017 began on May 29, 2016, and ended on May 27, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	Unless otherwise noted, all references to a particular year in this document shall mean our fiscal year.
355948_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe, and Latin America.
355948_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	Selected financial data attributable to each segment and geographic region for fiscal 2017, 2016, and 2015 is set forth in Note 11 Segment and Geographic Information of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
355948_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ), launched in July 2015, combines Electron Device Group s ( EDG ) core engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tube business with new RF and power technologies.
355948_17_ITEM1_P8_S1	As a manufacturer and authorized distributor, PMT s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_17_ITEM1_P8_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair all through our existing global infrastructure.
355948_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	PMT s focus is on products for power, RF and microwave applications for customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_17_ITEM1_P9_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	PMT represents leading manufacturers of electron tubes and components used in semiconductor manufacturing equipment and industrial power applications.
355948_17_ITEM1_P10_S1	Among the suppliers they support are Amperex, CPI, Draloric, Eimac, General Electric, Hitachi, Jennings, L3, MaCom, National, NJRC, Thales, Toshiba, and Vishay.
355948_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	PMT s inventory levels reflect our commitment to maintain an inventory of a broad range of products for customers who are buying products for replacement of components used in critical equipment.
355948_17_ITEM1_P11_S1	PMT also sells a number of products representing trailing edge technology.
355948_17_ITEM1_P11_S2	While the market for these trailing edge technology products is declining, PMT is increasing its market share.
355948_17_ITEM1_P11_S3	PMT often buys products it knows it can sell ahead of any supplier price increases.
355948_17_ITEM1_P11_S4	As manufacturers for these products exit the business, PMT has the option to purchase a substantial portion of their remaining inventory.
355948_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	PMT has distribution agreements with many of its suppliers; most of these agreements provide exclusive distribution rights which often include global coverage.
355948_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	The agreements are typically long term, and usually contain provisions permitting termination by either party if there are significant breaches which are not cured within a reasonable period of time.
355948_17_ITEM1_P12_S2	Although some of these agreements allow PMT to return inventory periodically, others do not, in which case PMT may have obsolete inventory that they cannot return to the supplier.
355948_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	PMT s suppliers provide warranty coverage for the products and allow return of defective products, including those returned to PMT by its customers.
355948_17_ITEM1_P13_S1	For information regarding the warranty reserves, see Note 3 Significant Accounting Policies of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
355948_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	In addition to third party products, we sell proprietary products principally under certain trade names we own including: Amperex , Cetron , and National .
355948_17_ITEM1_P14_S1	Our proprietary products include thyratrons and rectifiers, power tubes, ignitrons, magnetrons, phototubes, microwave generators, and liquid crystal display monitors.
355948_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	The materials used in the manufacturing process consist of glass bulbs and tubing, nickel, stainless steel and other metals, plastic and metal bases, ceramics, and a wide variety of fabricated metal components.
355948_17_ITEM1_P15_S1	These materials are generally readily available, but some components may require long lead times for production, and some materials are subject to shortages or price fluctuations based on supply and demand.
355948_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial, and medical original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ) markets.
355948_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	Our engineers design, manufacture, source, and support a full spectrum of solutions to match the needs of our customers.
355948_17_ITEM1_P16_S2	We offer custom display solutions that include touch screens, protective panels, custom enclosures, specialized cabinet finishes, and application specific software packages.
355948_17_ITEM1_P16_S3	Our volume commitments are much lower than those of the large display manufacturers, making us the ideal choice for companies with very specific design requirements.
355948_17_ITEM1_P16_S4	We partner with both private label manufacturing companies and leading branded hardware vendors to offer the high quality liquid crystal displays, mounting devices, and customized computing platforms.
355948_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	We have long-standing relationships with key component and finished goods manufacturers including 3M, LG, NEC Displays, and several key Asian display manufacturers that manufacture products to our specifications.
355948_17_ITEM1_P17_S1	We believe supplier relationships, combined with our engineering design and manufacturing capabilities and private label partnerships, allow us to maintain a well-balanced and technologically advanced offering of customer specific display solutions.
355948_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_17_ITEM1_P18_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts including CT and MRI tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	We have employees, as well as authorized representatives, who are not our employees, selling our products primarily in regions where we do not have a direct sales presence.
355948_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	We offer various credit terms to qualifying customers as well as cash in advance and credit card terms.
355948_17_ITEM1_P21_S1	We establish credit limits for each customer and routinely review delinquent and aging accounts.
355948_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	We maintain approximately 110,700 part numbers in our product inventory database and we estimate that more than 90% of orders received by 6:00 p.m. local time are shipped complete the same day if product is in stock.
355948_17_ITEM1_P22_S1	Customers can access our products on our web sites, www.rell.com , www.rellhealthcare.com, www.canvys.com, and www.rellaser.com, through electronic data interchange, or by telephone.
355948_17_ITEM1_P22_S2	Customer orders are processed by our regional sales offices and supported primarily by one of our distribution facilities in LaFox, Illinois; Amsterdam, Netherlands; Marlborough, Massachusetts; Donaueschingen, Germany; or Singapore, Singapore.
355948_17_ITEM1_P22_S3	We also have satellite warehouses in Sao Paulo, Brazil; Shanghai, China; Bangkok, Thailand; and Hook, United Kingdom.
355948_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our data processing network provides on-line, real-time interconnection of all sales offices and central distribution operations, 24 hours per day, seven days per week.
355948_17_ITEM1_P23_S1	Information on stock availability, pricing in local currency, cross-reference information, customers, and market analyses are obtainable throughout the entire distribution network.
355948_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	During fiscal 2017, approximately 60% of our sales were made outside the U.S.
355948_17_ITEM1_P24_S1	We continue to pursue new international sales to further expand our geographic reach.

355948_17_ITEM1_P25_S1	All of our employees are non-union, and we consider our relationships with our employees to be good.

355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should consider carefully the following risk factors in addition to the other information included and incorporated by reference in this Annual Report on Form 10-K that we believe are applicable to our businesses and the industries in which we operate.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	While we believe we have identified the key risk factors affecting our businesses, there may be additional risks and uncertainties that are not presently known or that are not currently believed to be significant that may adversely affect our results of operations.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	A significant portion of our cash, cash equivalents, and investments are held by our foreign subsidiaries and could affect future liquidity needs.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S3	We hold a significant amount of cash and investment securities at our foreign subsidiaries.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S4	Liquidity requirements could necessitate transfers of existing cash balances between our subsidiaries or to the United States that may be subject to restrictions or result in unfavorable tax or earnings consequences for those amounts that are not considered reinvested indefinitely.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S5	Approximately 76% of our cash and investment securities are held by our foreign subsidiaries.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S6	While we intend to use some of the cash held outside the United States to fund our international operations and growth, when we encounter a significant need for liquidity domestically or at a particular location that we cannot fulfill through other internal or external sources, we may experience unfavorable tax, earnings and liquidity consequences due to cash transfers.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P0_S7	These adverse consequences would occur, for example, if the transfer of cash into the United Sates is taxed and no offsetting foreign tax credit or net operating loss carryforward is available to offset the U.S. tax liability, resulting in lower earnings and liquidity.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We do not provide for U.S. taxes on the undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries that are considered to be reinvested indefinitely.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P1_S1	We may not achieve our plan for sales growth and margin targets.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We have established both margin and expense targets to grow our sales with new and existing customers.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	If we do not achieve our growth objectives, the complexity of our global infrastructure makes it difficult to leverage our fixed cost structure to align with the size of our operations.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Factors that could have a significant effect on our ability to achieve these goals include the following:
355948_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Limitations on our ability to leverage our support-function cost structure while maintaining an adequate structure to achieve our growth objectives.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We have historically incurred significant charges for inventory obsolescence, and may incur similar charges in the future.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We maintain significant inventories in an effort to ensure that customers have a reliable source of supply.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Our products generally support industrial machinery that is powered by tube technology.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P5_S2	As technology evolves and this capital equipment is replaced, the market for our products potentially declines.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P5_S3	In addition, the market for many of our other products is characterized by rapid change resulting from the development of new technologies, evolving industry standards, frequent new product introductions by some of our suppliers and changing end-user demand, which can contribute to the decline in value or obsolescence of our inventory.
355948_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We do not have many long-term supply contracts with our customers.

355948_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value flat panel detector solutions, replacement parts, tubes and service training for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_17_ITEM7_P4_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM7_P4_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_17_ITEM7_P4_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_17_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_17_ITEM7_P5_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	On June 15, 2015, Richardson Electronics, Ltd ( the Company ), acquired certain assets of International Medical Equipment and Services, Inc. ( IMES ), for a purchase price of $12.2 million.
355948_17_ITEM7_P6_S1	This includes the purchase of inventory, receivables, fixed assets, and certain other assets of the Company.
355948_17_ITEM7_P6_S2	The Company did not acquire any liabilities of IMES.
355948_17_ITEM7_P6_S3	The total consideration paid excludes transaction costs.
355948_17_ITEM7_P7_S0	IMES, based in South Carolina, provides reliable, cost-saving solutions worldwide for major brands of CT and MRI equipment.
355948_17_ITEM7_P7_S1	This acquisition positions Richardson Healthcare to provide cost effective diagnostic imaging replacement parts and training to hospitals, diagnostic imaging centers, medical institutions, and independent service organizations.
355948_17_ITEM7_P7_S2	IMES offers an extensive selection of replacement parts, as well as an interactive training center, on-site test bays and experienced technicians who provide 24/7 customer support.
355948_17_ITEM7_P7_S3	Replacement parts are readily available and triple tested to provide peace of mind when uptime is critical.
355948_17_ITEM7_P8_S0	IMES core operations have remained in South Carolina.
355948_17_ITEM7_P8_S1	Richardson Healthcare plans to expand IMES replacement parts and training offerings geographically leveraging the Company s global infrastructure.

355948_17_ITEM7_P9_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_17_ITEM7_P10_S0	Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ), launched in July 2015, combines Electron Device Group s ( EDG ) core engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tube business with new RF and power technologies.
355948_17_ITEM7_P10_S1	As a manufacturer and authorized distributor, PMT s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_17_ITEM7_P10_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair all through our existing global infrastructure.
355948_17_ITEM7_P11_S0	PMT s focus is on products for power, RF and microwave applications for customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM7_P11_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_17_ITEM7_P11_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_17_ITEM7_P12_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial, and medical original equipment manufacturers ( OEM ) markets.
355948_17_ITEM7_P13_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_17_ITEM7_P13_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts including CT and MRI tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_17_ITEM7_P14_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.

355948_17_ITEM7_P40_S0	Management assesses the available positive and negative evidence to estimate if sufficient future taxable income will be generated to use the existing deferred tax assets.
355948_17_ITEM7_P40_S1	A significant component of objective evidence evaluated was the cumulative income or loss incurred in each jurisdiction over the three-year period ended May 27, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM7_P40_S2	Such objective evidence limits the ability to consider subjective evidence such as future income projections.
355948_17_ITEM7_P40_S3	We considered other positive evidence in determining the need for a valuation allowance in the U.S. including the repatriation of foreign earnings which we do not consider permanently reinvested in certain of our foreign subsidiaries.
355948_17_ITEM7_P40_S4	The weight of this positive evidence is not sufficient to outweigh other negative evidence in evaluating our need for a valuation allowance in the U.S. jurisdiction.
355948_17_ITEM7_P41_S0	As of May 27, 2017, a valuation allowance of $8.5 million has been established to record only the portion of the deferred tax asset that will more likely than not be realized.

355948_17_ITEM7_P42_S2	The amount of the deferred tax asset considered realizable, however, could be adjusted if estimates of future taxable income during the carryforward period are increased, or if objective negative evidence in the form of cumulative losses is no longer present and additional weight may be given to subjective evidence such as our projections for growth.
