355948_17_ITEM7_P67_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ) requires management to make significant estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
355948_17_ITEM7_P67_S1	Management continuously evaluates its critical accounting policies and estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, revenue recognition, inventory obsolescence, goodwill and other intangible assets, loss contingencies, and income taxes.
355948_17_ITEM7_P67_S2	Management bases the estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, however, actual results could differ from those estimates.
355948_17_ITEM7_P68_S0	The policies discussed below are considered by management to be critical to understanding our financial position and the results of operations.
355948_17_ITEM7_P68_S1	Their application involves significant judgments and estimates in preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM7_P68_S2	For all of these policies, management cautions that future events rarely develop exactly as forecasted, and the best estimates routinely require adjustment.
355948_17_ITEM7_P69_S0	Our allowance for doubtful accounts includes estimated losses that result from uncollectible receivables.
355948_17_ITEM7_P69_S1	The estimates are influenced by the following: continuing credit evaluation of customers financial conditions; aging of receivables, individually and in the aggregate; a large number of customers which are widely dispersed across geographic areas; collectability and delinquency history by geographic area; and the fact that no single customer accounts for more than 10% of net sales.
355948_17_ITEM7_P69_S2	Significant changes in one or more of these considerations may require adjustments affecting net income and net carrying value of accounts receivable.
355948_17_ITEM7_P70_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts was approximately $0.4 million as of May 27, 2017, and $0.4 million as of May 28, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM7_P71_S0	Our product sales are recognized as revenue upon shipment, when title passes to the customer, when delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, and when collectability is reasonably assured.
355948_17_ITEM7_P71_S1	We also record estimated discounts and returns based on our historical experience.
355948_17_ITEM7_P71_S2	Our products are often manufactured to meet the specific design needs of our customers applications.
355948_17_ITEM7_P71_S3	Our engineers work closely with customers to ensure that our products will meet their needs.
355948_17_ITEM7_P71_S4	Our customers are under no obligation to compensate us for designing the products we sell.
355948_17_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our worldwide inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market, generally using a weighted-average cost method.
355948_17_ITEM7_P72_S1	Our net inventories included approximately $36.0 million of finished goods, $5.3 million of raw materials, and $1.4 million of work-in-progress as of May 27, 2017, as compared to approximately $40.0 million of finished goods, $4.4 million of raw materials, and $1.0 million of work-in-progress as of May 28, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM7_P73_S0	Provisions for obsolete or slow moving inventories are recorded based upon regular analysis of stock rotation privileges, obsolescence, the exiting of certain market segments, and assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
355948_17_ITEM7_P73_S1	If future demand, changes in the industry, or market conditions differ from management s estimates, additional provisions may be necessary.
355948_17_ITEM7_P74_S0	We recorded provisions to our inventory reserves of $0.5 million, $0.7 million, and $0.2 million during fiscal 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively, which were included in cost of sales.
355948_17_ITEM7_P74_S1	The provisions were primarily for obsolete and slow moving parts.
355948_17_ITEM7_P74_S2	The parts were written down to estimated realizable value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P75_S0	There was $6.3 million of goodwill reported on our balance sheet at both May 27, 2017 and May 28, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM7_P75_S1	The goodwill balance in its entirety relates to our IMES reporting unit which is included in the Healthcare segment.
355948_17_ITEM7_P76_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_17_ITEM7_P77_S0	During the fourth quarter of each fiscal year, our goodwill balances are reviewed for impairment using the first day of our fourth quarter as the measurement date.
355948_17_ITEM7_P77_S1	If after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in ASU 2011-08 we determine that it is not likely that the fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, then we test for impairment through the application of a fair value based test.
355948_17_ITEM7_P77_S2	We estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units based on projected future operating results, market approach, and discounted cash flows.
355948_17_ITEM7_P78_S0	Our goodwill impairment testing follows the two-step process as defined in ASC 350.
355948_17_ITEM7_P79_S0	The first step in the process compares the fair value of the reporting unit to its carrying value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P79_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recognized.
355948_17_ITEM7_P79_S2	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit resulting from the first step of the evaluation is allocated to the fair value of all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit in order to determine an implied goodwill value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P79_S3	This allocation is similar to the purchase price allocation performed in purchase accounting.
355948_17_ITEM7_P80_S0	If the carrying amount of the goodwill reported exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss should be recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
355948_17_ITEM7_P81_S0	After reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in ASU 2011-08, we determined that it was not more likely than not that the fair value for the IMES reporting unit exceeded its carrying value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P81_S1	Accordingly, the first step of the two step goodwill impairment test as described in FASB ASC 350-20-35 was performed.
355948_17_ITEM7_P82_S0	We performed the first step of the two step impairment test using the income method, which is based on a discounted future cash flow approach that uses the significant assumptions of projected revenue, projected operational profit, terminal growth rates, and the cost of capital.
355948_17_ITEM7_P83_S0	The results of our goodwill impairment test as of February 26, 2017 indicated that the value of goodwill attributed to our IMES reporting unit was not impaired.
355948_17_ITEM7_P84_S0	Since the acquisition of IMES in June 2015, there have been no fundamental changes in the business or market that would indicate a significant decline in the fair value since the acquisition date.
355948_17_ITEM7_P84_S1	In the two years since acquisition, the Company has made significant investments in the IMES business, including $6 million in capital expenditures that are expected to increase IMES product offerings and result in increased future sales, operating profit and cash flows.
355948_17_ITEM7_P85_S0	Management s projections used to estimate the undiscounted cash flows included increasing sales volumes from new product offerings being developed and expanded sales into new geographies and operational improvements designed to reduce costs.
355948_17_ITEM7_P85_S1	Changes in any of the significant assumptions used, including if the Company does not successfully achieve its operating plan, which is dependent on the creation of new product offerings, can materially affect the expected cash flows, and such impacts could result in a material non-cash impairment charge of goodwill and other long lived assets.
355948_17_ITEM7_P86_S0	Although we believe our projected future operating results and cash flows and related estimates regarding fair values are based on reasonable assumptions, historically, projected operating results and cash flows have not always been achieved.
355948_17_ITEM7_P87_S0	Intangible assets are initially recorded at their fair market values determined on quoted market prices in active markets, if available, or recognized valuation models.
355948_17_ITEM7_P87_S1	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized on a straight-line basis over their useful lives.
355948_17_ITEM7_P87_S2	Our intangible assets represent the fair value for trade name, customer relationships, non-compete agreements, and technology acquired in connection with the acquisitions.
355948_17_ITEM7_P88_S0	We review property and equipment, definite-lived intangible assets, and other long-lived assets for impairment whenever adverse events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amounts of such assets may not be recoverable.
355948_17_ITEM7_P89_S0	If adverse events do occur, our impairment review is based on an undiscounted cash flow analysis at the lowest level at which cash flows of the long-lived assets are largely independent of other groups of our assets and liabilities.
355948_17_ITEM7_P89_S1	This analysis requires management judgment with respect to changes in technology, the continued success of product lines, and future volume, revenue and expense growth rates.
355948_17_ITEM7_P89_S2	We conduct annual reviews for idle and underutilized equipment, and review business plans for possible impairment.
355948_17_ITEM7_P90_S0	Impairment occurs when the carrying value of the assets exceeds the future undiscounted cash flows expected to be earned by the use of the asset or asset group.
355948_17_ITEM7_P90_S1	When impairment is indicated, the estimated future cash flows are then discounted to determine the estimated fair value of the asset or asset group and an impairment charge is recorded for the difference between the carrying value and the estimated fair value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P91_S0	Additionally, we also evaluate the remaining useful life each reporting period to determine whether events and circumstances warrant a revision to the remaining period of depreciation or amortization.
355948_17_ITEM7_P92_S0	If the estimate of a long lived asset s remaining useful life is changed, the remaining carrying amount of the asset is amortized prospectively over that revised remaining useful life.
355948_17_ITEM7_P93_S0	We accrue a liability for loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
355948_17_ITEM7_P93_S1	When only a range of possible losses can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_17_ITEM7_P93_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_17_ITEM7_P94_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_17_ITEM7_P95_S0	We recognize deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the differences between financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of assets and liabilities.
355948_17_ITEM7_P95_S1	We regularly review our deferred tax assets for recoverability and determine the need for a valuation allowance based on a number of factors, including both positive and negative evidence.
355948_17_ITEM7_P95_S2	These factors include historical taxable income or loss, projected future taxable income or loss, the expected timing of the reversals of existing temporary differences, and the implementation of tax planning strategies.
355948_17_ITEM7_P95_S3	In circumstances where we, or any of our affiliates, have incurred three years of cumulative losses which constitute significant negative evidence, positive evidence of equal or greater significance is needed to overcome the negative evidence before a tax benefit is recognized for deductible temporary differences and loss carryforwards.
355948_17_ITEM7_P95_S4	See Note 9 Income Taxes of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further information.
355948_17_ITEM7_P96_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09 ( ASU 2014-09 ), Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which amends guidance for revenue recognition.
355948_17_ITEM7_P96_S1	ASU 2014-09 is principles based guidance that can be applied to all contracts with customers, enhancing comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions and capital markets.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that entities should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S1	The guidance details the steps entities should apply to achieve the core principle.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S2	In August 2015, the FASB issued an amendment to defer the effective date for all entities by one year.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S3	For public entities, ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S4	Early adoption is permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S5	Companies have the option of using either a full or modified retrospective approach in applying this standard.
355948_17_ITEM7_P97_S6	During fiscal 2016 and 2017, the FASB issued four additional updates which further clarify the guidance provided in ASU 2014-09.
355948_17_ITEM7_P98_S0	We are evaluating the impact of the new standard on our financial statements using a three-phase approach (assessment, conversion and implementation).
355948_17_ITEM7_P98_S1	We are in our primary assessment stage, which included identifying revenue streams, contracts and responsible parties who create and manage those accounts, quantifying the impact of identified contracts on the financial statements and identifying internal control changes.
355948_17_ITEM7_P98_S2	We are in the initial stage of our assessment phase and therefore further evaluation is needed to determine the impact on our financial statements, related disclosures and controls upon adoption.
355948_17_ITEM7_P98_S3	We expect to finalize the primary assessment phase in the first quarter of fiscal 2018.
355948_17_ITEM7_P98_S4	We will complete the conversion and implementation phases during fiscal 2018 in conjunction with future interpretative guidance.
355948_17_ITEM7_P99_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11 ( ASU 2015-11 ), Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
355948_17_ITEM7_P99_S1	ASU 2015-11 requires inventory within the scope of the ASU (e.g., first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) or average cost) to be measured using the lower of cost and net realizable value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P99_S2	Inventory excluded from the scope of the ASU (i.e., last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) or the retail inventory method) will continue to be measured at the lower of cost or market.
355948_17_ITEM7_P99_S3	The ASU also amends some of the other guidance in Topic 330, Inventory, to more clearly articulate the requirements for the measurement and disclosure of inventory.
355948_17_ITEM7_P99_S4	However, those amendments are not intended to result in any changes to current practice.
355948_17_ITEM7_P100_S0	ASU 2015-11 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_17_ITEM7_P100_S1	The Company does not expect adoption of ASU 2015-11 to have a material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM7_P101_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes.
355948_17_ITEM7_P101_S1	ASU 2015-17 eliminates the prior US GAAP guidance in Topic 740, Income Taxes, that required an entity to separate deferred tax liabilities and assets between current and noncurrent amounts in a classified balance sheet.
355948_17_ITEM7_P101_S2	The amendments in ASU 2015-17 require that all deferred tax liabilities and assets of the same tax jurisdiction or a tax filing group, as well as any related valuation allowance, be offset and presented as a single noncurrent amount in a classified balance sheet.
355948_17_ITEM7_P101_S3	ASU 2015-17 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_17_ITEM7_P101_S4	In order to simplify presentation of deferred tax balances, the Company adopted this standard prospectively in the quarter ended August 27, 2016, which did not have a material impact on the Company s results of operations, cash flows or stockholders equity.
355948_17_ITEM7_P101_S5	Periods prior to August 27, 2016 were not retrospectively adjusted.
355948_17_ITEM7_P102_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02 ( ASU 2016-02 ), Leases.
355948_17_ITEM7_P102_S1	ASU 2016-02 establishes a right-of-use ( ROU ) model that requires a lessee to record an ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer than 12 months.
355948_17_ITEM7_P102_S2	Leases will be classified as either finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the income statement.
355948_17_ITEM7_P103_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
355948_17_ITEM7_P104_S0	A modified retrospective transition approach is required for lessees for capital and operating leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in the financial statements, with certain practical expedients available.
355948_17_ITEM7_P104_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of ASU 2016-02 on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM7_P104_S2	Upon adoption, the Company expects that the amounts recognized for the ROU asset and lease liability in the balance sheets may be material.

355948_17_ITEM7_P105_S1	ASU 2016-09 introduces targeted amendments intended to simplify the accounting for stock compensation.
355948_17_ITEM7_P105_S2	ASU 2016-09 will directly impact the tax administration of equity plans.
355948_17_ITEM7_P105_S3	ASU 2016-09 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_17_ITEM7_P105_S4	Early adoption is permitted and any adjustments should be reflected as of the beginning of the fiscal year that includes that interim period.
355948_17_ITEM7_P105_S5	The Company expects to adopt ASU 2016-09 in the first quarter of fiscal 2018, at which time we will evaluate the potential impact of the adoption of this standard on the Company s consolidated financial statements.

355948_17_ITEM7_P106_S1	ASU 2016-15 will make eight targeted changes to how cash receipts and cash payments are presented and classified in the statement of cash flows.
355948_17_ITEM7_P106_S2	ASU 2016-15 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017.

355948_17_ITEM7_P107_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04 ( ASU 2017-04 ), Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
355948_17_ITEM7_P107_S1	ASU 2017-04 eliminates step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
355948_17_ITEM7_P107_S2	As amended, the goodwill impairment test will consist of one step comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
355948_17_ITEM7_P107_S3	An entity should recognize a goodwill impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value.
355948_17_ITEM7_P107_S4	An entity may still perform the optional qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
355948_17_ITEM7_P108_S0	ASU 2017-04 will be effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019.
355948_17_ITEM7_P108_S1	ASU 2017-04 is required to be applied prospectively and early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM7_P108_S2	The Company is currently in the process of evaluating the impact of adoption on its consolidated financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are exposed to many different market risks with the various industries we serve.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The primary financial risk we are exposed to is foreign currency exchange, as certain operations, assets, and liabilities of ours are denominated in foreign currencies.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We manage these risks through normal operating and financing activities.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The interpretation and analysis of these disclosures should not be considered in isolation since such variances in exchange rates would likely influence other economic factors.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Such factors, which are not readily quantifiable, would likely also affect our operations.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P1_S2	Additional disclosure regarding various market risks are set forth in Part I, Item 1A, Risk Factors of our Annual Report on this Form 10-K.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Even though we take into account current foreign currency exchange rates at the time an order is taken, our financial statements, denominated in a non-U.S. functional currency, are subject to foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Our foreign denominated assets and liabilities are cash, accounts receivable, inventory, accounts payable and intercompany receivables and payables, as we conduct business in countries of the European Union, Asia/Pacific and, to a lesser extent, Canada and Latin America.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P3_S1	We do manage foreign exchange exposures by using currency clauses in certain sales contracts and we also have local debt to offset asset exposures.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P3_S2	We have not used any derivative instruments nor entered into any forward contracts in fiscal 2017, fiscal 2016, or fiscal 2015.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Had the U.S. dollar changed unfavorably 10% against various foreign currencies, foreign denominated net sales would have been lower by an estimated $9.1 million during fiscal 2017, an estimated $9.9 million during fiscal 2016, and an estimated $9.6 million during fiscal 2015.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Total assets would have declined by an estimated $5.2 million as of the fiscal year ended May 27, 2017, and an estimated $6.5 million as of the fiscal year ended May 28, 2016, while the total liabilities would have decreased by an estimated $0.9 million as of the fiscal year ended May 27, 2017, and an estimated $0.9 million as of the fiscal year ended May 28, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The interpretation and analysis of these disclosures should not be considered in isolation since such variances in exchanges rates would likely influence other economic factors.
355948_17_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Such factors, which are not readily quantifiable, would likely also affect our operations.
355948_17_ITEM8_P0_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value flat panel detector solutions, replacement parts, tubes and service training for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_17_ITEM8_P0_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P0_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_17_ITEM8_P0_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_17_ITEM8_P1_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_17_ITEM8_P1_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_17_ITEM8_P2_S0	During the first quarter of fiscal 2015, we created a new strategic business unit called Richardson Healthcare ( Healthcare ).
355948_17_ITEM8_P3_S0	As hospitals remain under pressure to reduce costs while serving a much larger customer base, there is a growing demand for independent sources of high-value replacement parts for diagnostic imaging.
355948_17_ITEM8_P3_S1	Having access to parts that are tested and in stock enables hospitals to terminate expensive service contracts with the Original Equipment Manufacturers ( OEM ) and instead use third party service providers or in-house technicians.
355948_17_ITEM8_P3_S2	With our global infrastructure, technical sales team, and experience servicing the healthcare market, we are well positioned to take advantage of this market opportunity.
355948_17_ITEM8_P3_S3	Over time, our plan is to expand our position from being the leader in power grid tubes to a key player in the high-growth, high-profile healthcare industry.
355948_17_ITEM8_P4_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_17_ITEM8_P5_S0	The Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ), formerly called the Electron Device Group ( EDG ) prior to July 2015, provides engineered solutions and distributes electronic components to customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P5_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_17_ITEM8_P5_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_17_ITEM8_P6_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial, and medical OEM markets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P7_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_17_ITEM8_P7_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts including CT and MRI tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_17_ITEM8_P8_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_17_ITEM8_P9_S0	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe, and Latin America.
355948_17_ITEM8_P10_S0	Customer Concentration: No one customer represented more than 10% of our total accounts receivable balance as of May 27, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM8_P10_S1	One customer represented $3.8 million, or 15%, of our total accounts receivable balance, as of May 28, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM8_P10_S2	This receivable was collected in the first month of our fiscal 2017.
355948_17_ITEM8_P10_S3	No one customer represented more than 10% of net sales for either fiscal 2017 or fiscal 2016.

355948_17_ITEM8_P15_S0	Use of Estimates: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make significant estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
355948_17_ITEM8_P15_S1	Management continuously evaluates its critical accounting policies and estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, revenue recognition, inventory obsolescence, goodwill and other intangible assets, loss contingencies, and income taxes.
355948_17_ITEM8_P15_S2	Management bases the estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, however, actual results could differ from those estimates.

355948_17_ITEM8_P17_S1	The carrying amounts reported in the balance sheet for cash and cash equivalents approximate the fair market value of these assets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P18_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts: Our allowance for doubtful accounts includes estimated losses that result from uncollectible receivables.

355948_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	Loss Contingencies: We accrue a liability for loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
355948_17_ITEM8_P20_S1	When only a range of possible loss can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_17_ITEM8_P20_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	Our product sales are recognized as revenue upon shipment, when title passes to the customer, when delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, and when collectability is reasonably assured.
355948_17_ITEM8_P22_S1	We also record estimated discounts and returns based on our historical experience.
355948_17_ITEM8_P22_S2	Our products are often manufactured to meet the specific design needs of our customers applications.
355948_17_ITEM8_P22_S3	Our engineers work closely with customers to ensure that our products will meet their needs.
355948_17_ITEM8_P22_S4	Our customers are under no obligation to compensate us for designing the products we sell.
355948_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	The functional currency is the local currency at all foreign locations, with the exception of Hong Kong, which the functional currency is the US dollar.
355948_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	Balance sheet items for our foreign entities, included in our consolidated balance sheet are translated into U.S. dollars at end-of-period spot rates.
355948_17_ITEM8_P24_S1	Gains and losses resulting from translation of foreign subsidiary financial statements are credited or charged directly to accumulated other comprehensive income/(loss), a component of stockholders equity.
355948_17_ITEM8_P24_S2	Revenues and expenses are translated at the current rate on the date of the transaction.
355948_17_ITEM8_P24_S3	Gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transactions are included in income.
355948_17_ITEM8_P24_S4	Foreign currency translation reflected in our consolidated statements of comprehensive loss was a loss of $0.6 million during fiscal 2017, a loss of $0.2 million during fiscal 2016, and a gain of $0.2 million during fiscal 2015.
355948_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	Shipping and Handling Fees and Costs: Shipping and handling costs billed to customers are reported as revenue and the related costs are reported as a component of cost of sales.
355948_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	Inventories, net: Our worldwide inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market, generally using a weighted-average cost method.
355948_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	Our net inventories include approximately $36.0 million of finished goods, $5.3 million of raw materials, and $1.4 million of work-in-progress as of May 27, 2017, as compared to approximately $40.0 million of finished goods, $4.4 million of raw materials, and $1.0 million of work-in-progress as of May 28, 2016.

355948_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	Provisions for obsolete or slow moving inventories are recorded based upon regular analysis of stock rotation privileges, obsolescence, the exiting of certain markets, and assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
355948_17_ITEM8_P27_S1	If future demand, changes in the industry, or market conditions differ from management s estimates, additional provisions may be necessary.
355948_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	We recorded provisions to our inventory reserves of $0.5 million, $0.7 million, and $0.2 million during fiscal 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively, which were included in cost of sales.
355948_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	The provisions were principally for obsolete and slow moving parts.
355948_17_ITEM8_P28_S2	The parts were written down to estimated realizable value.
355948_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	Income Taxes: We recognize deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the differences between financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of assets and liabilities.
355948_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	We regularly review our deferred tax assets for recoverability and determine the need for a valuation allowance based on a number of factors, including both positive and negative evidence.
355948_17_ITEM8_P29_S2	These factors include historical taxable income or loss, projected future taxable income or loss, the expected timing of the reversals of existing temporary differences, and the implementation of tax planning strategies.
355948_17_ITEM8_P29_S3	In circumstances where we, or any of our affiliates, have incurred three years of cumulative losses which constitute significant negative evidence, positive evidence of equal or greater significance is needed to overcome the negative evidence before a tax benefit is recognized for deductible temporary differences and loss carryforwards.

355948_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets: We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	During the fourth quarter of each fiscal year, our goodwill balances are reviewed for impairment using the first day of our fourth quarter as the measurement date.
355948_17_ITEM8_P36_S1	If after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in ASU 2011-08 we determine that it is not likely that the fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, then we test for impairment through the application of a fair value based test.
355948_17_ITEM8_P36_S2	We estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units based on projected future operating results, market approach, and discounted cash flows.
355948_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	Our goodwill impairment testing follows the two-step process as defined in ASC 350.
355948_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	The first step in the process compares the fair value of the reporting unit to its carrying value.
355948_17_ITEM8_P38_S1	If the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss to be recognized.
355948_17_ITEM8_P38_S2	In the second step, the fair value of the reporting unit resulting from the first step of the evaluation is allocated to the fair value of all of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit in order to determine an implied goodwill value.
355948_17_ITEM8_P38_S3	This allocation is similar to the purchase price allocation performed in purchase accounting.
355948_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	If the carrying amount of the goodwill reported exceeds the implied goodwill value, an impairment loss should be recognized in an amount equal to that excess.
355948_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	Intangible assets are initially recorded at their fair market values determined on quoted market prices in active markets, if available, or recognized valuation models.
355948_17_ITEM8_P40_S1	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized on a straight-line basis over their useful lives.
355948_17_ITEM8_P40_S2	Our intangible assets represent the fair value for trade name, customer relationships, non-compete agreements, and technology acquired in connection with the acquisitions.
355948_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	Property, Plant and Equipment: Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost, net of accumulated depreciation.
355948_17_ITEM8_P41_S1	Improvements and replacements are capitalized while expenditures for maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred.
355948_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	Provisions for depreciation are computed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life of the asset.
355948_17_ITEM8_P42_S1	Depreciation expense was approximately $2.4 million, $2.0 million, and $1.7 million during fiscal 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively.

355948_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	In accordance with ASC 260-10, Earnings Per Share ( ASC 260 ), our Class B common stock is considered a participating security requiring the use of the two-class method for the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share.
355948_17_ITEM8_P66_S1	The two-class computation method for each period reflects the cash dividends paid per share for each class of stock, plus the amount of allocated undistributed earnings per share computed using the participation percentage which reflects the dividend rights of each class of stock.

355948_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09 ( ASU 2014-09 ), Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which amends guidance for revenue recognition.
355948_17_ITEM8_P70_S1	ASU 2014-09 is principles based guidance that can be applied to all contracts with customers, enhancing comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions and capital markets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that entities should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S1	The guidance details the steps entities should apply to achieve the core principle.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S2	In August 2015, the FASB issued an amendment to defer the effective date for all entities by one year.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S3	For public entities, ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S4	Early adoption is permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S5	Companies have the option of using either a full or modified retrospective approach in applying this standard.
355948_17_ITEM8_P71_S6	During fiscal 2016 and 2017, the FASB issued four additional updates which further clarify the guidance provided in ASU 2014-09.
355948_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	We are evaluating the impact of the new standard on our financial statements using a three-phase approach (assessment, conversion and implementation).
355948_17_ITEM8_P72_S1	We are in our primary assessment stage, which included identifying revenue streams, contracts and responsible parties who create and manage those accounts, quantifying the impact of identified contracts on the financial statements and identifying internal control changes.
355948_17_ITEM8_P72_S2	We are in the initial stage of our assessment phase and therefore further evaluation is needed to determine the impact on our financial statements, related disclosures and controls upon adoption.
355948_17_ITEM8_P72_S3	We expect to finalize the primary assessment phase in the first quarter of fiscal 2018.
355948_17_ITEM8_P72_S4	We will complete the conversion and implementation phases during fiscal 2018 in conjunction with future interpretative guidance.
355948_17_ITEM8_P73_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11 ( ASU 2015-11 ), Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
355948_17_ITEM8_P73_S1	ASU 2015-11 requires inventory within the scope of the ASU (e.g., first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) or average cost) to be measured using the lower of cost and net realizable value.
355948_17_ITEM8_P73_S2	Inventory excluded from the scope of the ASU (i.e., last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) or the retail inventory method) will continue to be measured at the lower of cost or market.
355948_17_ITEM8_P73_S3	The ASU also amends some of the other guidance in Topic 330, Inventory, to more clearly articulate the requirements for the measurement and disclosure of inventory.
355948_17_ITEM8_P73_S4	However, those amendments are not intended to result in any changes to current practice.
355948_17_ITEM8_P74_S0	ASU 2015-11 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_17_ITEM8_P74_S1	The Company does not expect adoption of ASU 2015-11 to have a material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM8_P75_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes.
355948_17_ITEM8_P75_S1	ASU 2015-17 eliminates the prior US GAAP guidance in Topic 740, Income Taxes, that required an entity to separate deferred tax liabilities and assets between current and noncurrent amounts in a classified balance sheet.
355948_17_ITEM8_P75_S2	The amendments in ASU 2015-17 require that all deferred tax liabilities and assets of the same tax jurisdiction or a tax filing group, as well as any related valuation allowance, be offset and presented as a single noncurrent amount in a classified balance sheet.
355948_17_ITEM8_P75_S3	ASU 2015-17 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_17_ITEM8_P75_S4	In order to simplify presentation of deferred tax balances, the Company adopted this standard prospectively in the quarter ended August 27, 2016, which did not have a material impact on the Company s results of operations, cash flows or stockholders equity.
355948_17_ITEM8_P75_S5	Periods prior to August 27, 2016 were not retrospectively adjusted.
355948_17_ITEM8_P76_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02 ( ASU 2016-02 ), Leases.
355948_17_ITEM8_P76_S1	ASU 2016-02 establishes a right-of-use ( ROU ) model that requires a lessee to record an ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer than 12 months.
355948_17_ITEM8_P76_S2	Leases will be classified as either finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the income statement.
355948_17_ITEM8_P77_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
355948_17_ITEM8_P78_S0	A modified retrospective transition approach is required for lessees for capital and operating leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in the financial statements, with certain practical expedients available.
355948_17_ITEM8_P78_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of ASU 2016-02 on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM8_P78_S2	Upon adoption, the Company expects that the amounts recognized for the ROU asset and lease liability in the balance sheets may be material.

355948_17_ITEM8_P79_S1	ASU 2016-09 introduces targeted amendments intended to simplify the accounting for stock compensation.

355948_17_ITEM8_P80_S1	ASU 2016-15 will make eight targeted changes to how cash receipts and cash payments are presented and classified in the statement of cash flows.

355948_17_ITEM8_P81_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04 ( ASU 2017-04 ), Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
355948_17_ITEM8_P81_S1	ASU 2017-04 eliminates step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
355948_17_ITEM8_P81_S2	As amended, the goodwill impairment test will consist of one step comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
355948_17_ITEM8_P81_S3	An entity should recognize a goodwill impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value.
355948_17_ITEM8_P81_S4	An entity may still perform the optional qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
355948_17_ITEM8_P82_S0	ASU 2017-04 will be effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019.
355948_17_ITEM8_P82_S1	ASU 2017-04 is required to be applied prospectively and early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM8_P82_S2	The Company is currently in the process of evaluating the impact of adoption on its consolidated financial statements.

355948_17_ITEM8_P84_S0	IMES, based in South Carolina, provides reliable, cost-saving solutions worldwide for major brands of CT and MRI equipment.

355948_17_ITEM8_P129_S0	During the first quarter of fiscal 2015, we created a new strategic business unit called Healthcare.
355948_17_ITEM8_P130_S0	As hospitals remain under pressure to reduce costs while serving a much larger customer base, there is a growing demand for independent sources of high value replacement parts for diagnostic imaging.
355948_17_ITEM8_P130_S1	Having access to parts that are tested and in stock enables hospitals to terminate expensive service contracts with OEM and instead use third party service providers or in-house technicians.
355948_17_ITEM8_P130_S2	With our global infrastructure, technical sales team, and experience servicing the healthcare market, we are well positioned to take advantage of this market opportunity.
355948_17_ITEM8_P130_S3	Over time, our plan is to expand our position from being the leader in power grid tubes to a key player in the high-growth, high-profile Healthcare industry.
355948_17_ITEM8_P131_S0	In accordance with ASC 280-10, Segment Reporting , we have identified three reportable segments: PMT and Canvys, and Healthcare.
355948_17_ITEM8_P132_S0	The Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ), formerly called the Electron Device Group ( EDG ), prior to July 2015, provides engineered solutions and distributes electronic components to customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific, and semiconductor markets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P132_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar, and radiation oncology.
355948_17_ITEM8_P132_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_17_ITEM8_P133_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial, and medical OEM markets.
355948_17_ITEM8_P134_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations, and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_17_ITEM8_P134_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts including CT and MRI tubes, hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; replacement flat panel detectors and upgrades; and additional replacement components currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_17_ITEM8_P135_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings, and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.

355948_17_ITEM8_P150_S0	ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures ( ASC 820 ), defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States, and expands disclosures about fair value measurements.
355948_17_ITEM8_P151_S0	ASC 820 establishes a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value.
355948_17_ITEM8_P151_S1	These tiers include: Level 1, defined as observable inputs such as quoted prices in active markets; Level 2, defined as inputs other than quoted prices in active markets that are either directly or indirectly observable; and Level 3, defined as unobservable inputs in which little or no market data exists; therefore requiring an entity to develop its own assumptions.

355948_17_ITEM8_P152_S1	Our investments consist of time deposits and CDs, where face value is equal to fair value, and equity securities of publicly traded companies for which market prices are readily available.

355948_17_ITEM8_P164_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
355948_17_ITEM8_P165_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
355948_17_ITEM8_P165_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
355948_17_ITEM8_P166_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
355948_17_ITEM8_P166_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
355948_17_ITEM8_P167_S0	In our opinion, Richardson Electronics, Ltd. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of May 27, 2017, based on the COSO criteria .
355948_17_ITEM8_P168_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Richardson Electronics, Ltd. as of May 27, 2017 and May 28, 2016 and the related consolidated statements of comprehensive loss, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended May 27, 2017 and our report dated July 31, 2017 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Management of the Company, with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer, evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act ) as of May 27, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Disclosure controls and procedures are intended to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in the Company s Exchange Act reports is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified by the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to management, including the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Based on this evaluation, the Company s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of May 27, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f).
355948_17_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness of future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P2_S0	A material weakness is a deficiency in internal control over financial reporting that results in more than a remote likelihood that a material misstatement of the annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected.
355948_17_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Under the supervision of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, management conducted an assessment of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of May 27, 2017, based on the framework in the Internal Control-Integrated Framework (2013) published by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ).
355948_17_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Based on that assessment, management has concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of May 27, 2017.

355948_17_ITEM9A_P5_S0	There have been no changes in the Company s internal control over financial reporting during the most recent fiscal year that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company s internal control over financial reporting.

355948_17_ITEM15_P43_S0	LaFox, IL, July 19, 2017: Richardson Electronics, Ltd. (NASDAQ: RELL) today reported financial results for its fourth quarter and fiscal year ended May 27, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM15_P43_S1	The Company also announced that its Board of Directors declared a $0.06 per share quarterly cash dividend.
355948_17_ITEM15_P44_S0	Net sales for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017 were $37.4 million compared to net sales of $39.6 million in the prior year s fourth quarter.
355948_17_ITEM15_P44_S1	Sales decreased $1.3 million for PMT, primarily due to a large government sale in the fourth quarter of 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P44_S2	PMT sales were higher in power conversion and RF and microwave components as well as specialty products sold into the semiconductor capital equipment market.
355948_17_ITEM15_P44_S3	Sales decreased by $0.9 million for Richardson Healthcare and sales were flat for Canvys as compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P45_S0	Gross margin decreased to $12.0 million, or 32.1% of net sales during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, compared to $13.4 million, or 33.8% of net sales during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P45_S1	Margin declined as a percent of net sales primarily due to an unfavorable product mix in both PMT and Richardson Healthcare.
355948_17_ITEM15_P46_S0	Operating expenses decreased to $12.2 million for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, compared to $13.7 million for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P46_S1	The decrease was due to reduced salaries, benefits and incentive compensation expenses relating to the reduction in force and changes to the incentive structure earlier in fiscal 2017.
355948_17_ITEM15_P46_S2	In addition, IT expenses were lower than in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P46_S3	These reductions were partially offset by $0.2 million in higher research and development expenses for Richardson Healthcare.
355948_17_ITEM15_P47_S0	In addition, there was a $0.2 million gain on the divestiture of the PACS Displays business completed in May 2017.
355948_17_ITEM15_P48_S0	As a result, the company reported $39,000 of operating income for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, compared to an operating loss of $0.3 million in the prior year s fourth quarter.
355948_17_ITEM15_P49_S0	Other expense for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, primarily foreign exchange, was $0.2 million, compared to less than $0.1 million for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P50_S0	The income tax benefit of less than $0.1 million during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017 reflected an adjustment to a tax reserve due to an expired statute of limitations, an adjustment to the provision for foreign income taxes and no U.S. tax benefit due to the valuation allowance recorded against the net operating loss.
355948_17_ITEM15_P51_S0	Net loss for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017 was $0.1 million, compared to a net loss of $0.2 million in the fourth quarter of 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P52_S0	Net sales for fiscal 2017 were $136.9 million, a decrease of 3.6%, compared to net sales of $142.0 million for fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P52_S1	Sales decreased by $2.9 million for Canvys, primarily due to declines in demand from key customers relating to market conditions.
355948_17_ITEM15_P52_S2	Sales for PMT decreased by $1.3 million due to the large government sale in fiscal 2016 that was not repeated in fiscal 2017, partially offset by sales from new niche technology suppliers.
355948_17_ITEM15_P52_S3	Sales for Richardson Healthcare decreased by $0.9 million as a result of lower sales in the PACS Displays business, which was divested on May 25, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM15_P53_S0	Gross profit decreased to $43.9 million, compared to $44.8 million for fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P53_S1	However, gross margin increased to 32.1% of net sales for fiscal 2017, compared to 31.6% of net sales for fiscal 2016, mostly as a result of an improved product mix.
355948_17_ITEM15_P54_S0	Operating expenses decreased to $49.9 million for fiscal 2017, compared to $51.6 million for fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P54_S1	Fiscal 2017 included $1.3 million in severance expense associated with the reduction in work force during the second quarter of fiscal 2017, which was more than offset by reduced salaries and incentive compensation expenses.
355948_17_ITEM15_P54_S2	In addition, IT expenses were nearly $0.9 million lower than fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P54_S3	These reductions were partially offset by $0.5 million in higher research and development expenses for Richardson Healthcare.
355948_17_ITEM15_P55_S0	Operating loss for fiscal 2017 was $5.8 million, compared to an operating loss of $6.6 million for fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P55_S1	After excluding the severance expense of $1.3 million, the operating loss would have been $4.5 million for fiscal year 2017.
355948_17_ITEM15_P56_S0	Other expense for fiscal 2017, including foreign exchange, was $0.4 million, compared to other income of $0.3 million for fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P57_S0	The income tax provision of $0.8 million for fiscal 2017 reflected a provision for foreign income taxes and no U.S. tax benefit due to the valuation allowance recorded against the net operating loss.
355948_17_ITEM15_P58_S0	Net loss for fiscal 2017 was $6.9 million, compared to a net loss of $6.8 million for fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P59_S0	The Company also announced today that its Board of Directors declared a $0.06 quarterly dividend per share to holders of common stock and a $0.054 cash dividend per share to holders of Class B common stock.
355948_17_ITEM15_P59_S1	The dividend will be payable on August 24, 2017, to common stockholders of record on August 7, 2017.
355948_17_ITEM15_P60_S0	Cash and investments at the end of the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017 were $64.2 million compared to $60.2 million at the end of the third quarter of fiscal 2017 and $70.5 million at the end of the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.
355948_17_ITEM15_P60_S1	During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017, the Company did not repurchase any shares of its common stock under the existing share repurchase authorization.
355948_17_ITEM15_P60_S2	Since the sale of RFPD, the Company has spent $65.6 million on share repurchases, nearly $20.0 million on acquisitions, approximately $20.0 million on dividends and $7.3 million on purchases of Richardson Healthcare equipment.
355948_17_ITEM15_P60_S3	Currently, there are 10.7 million outstanding shares of common stock and 2.1 million outstanding shares of Class B common stock.
355948_17_ITEM15_P61_S0	I am pleased to report an operating profit for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017 as compared to a $0.3 million operating loss in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, said Edward J. Richardson, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer, and President.
355948_17_ITEM15_P61_S1	The improvement in overall financial results, including generating an additional $4.0 million in cash flow from operations, is a direct result of our ongoing initiatives aimed at growing revenue, permanently reducing expenses and improving cash flow.
355948_17_ITEM15_P61_S2	We will continue to operate conservatively and preserve cash for investments in areas that will help return the company to profitability, Mr. Richardson concluded.

355948_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value flat panel detector solutions, replacement parts, tubes and service training for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_18_ITEM1_P0_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_18_ITEM1_P0_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_18_ITEM1_P0_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our fiscal year 2018 began on May 28, 2017 and ended on June 2, 2018, our fiscal year 2017 began on May 29, 2016 and ended on May 27, 2017 and our fiscal year 2016 began on May 31, 2015 and ended on May 28, 2016.
355948_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	Unless otherwise noted, all references to a particular year in this document shall mean our fiscal year.
355948_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe and Latin America.
355948_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	Selected financial data attributable to each segment and geographic region for fiscal 2018, 2017 and 2016 is set forth in Note 11 Segment and Geographic Information of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
355948_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ) combines our core engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tube business with new RF and power technologies.
355948_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	As a manufacturer and authorized distributor, PMT s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_18_ITEM1_P7_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics and aftermarket technical service and repair all through our existing global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	PMT s focus is on products for power, RF and microwave applications for customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_18_ITEM1_P8_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar and radiation oncology.
355948_18_ITEM1_P8_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_18_ITEM1_P9_S0	PMT represents leading manufacturers of electron tubes and solid-state components used in semiconductor manufacturing equipment, RF and wireless and industrial power applications.
355948_18_ITEM1_P9_S1	Among the suppliers they support are Amperex, CDE, CPI, Draloric, Eimac, General Electric, Hitachi, Jennings, L3, MACOM, National, NJRC, Ohmite, Qorvo, Thales, Toshiba and Vishay.
355948_18_ITEM1_P10_S0	PMT s inventory levels reflect our commitment to maintain an inventory of a broad range of products for customers who are buying products for replacement of components used in critical equipment and new technologies.
355948_18_ITEM1_P10_S1	PMT also sells a number of products representing trailing edge technology.
355948_18_ITEM1_P10_S2	While the market for these trailing edge technology products is declining, PMT is increasing its market share.
355948_18_ITEM1_P10_S3	PMT often buys products it knows it can sell ahead of any supplier price increases.
355948_18_ITEM1_P10_S4	As manufacturers for these products exit the business, PMT has the option to purchase a substantial portion of their remaining inventory.
355948_18_ITEM1_P11_S0	PMT has distribution agreements with many of its suppliers; most of these agreements provide exclusive distribution rights which often include global coverage.
355948_18_ITEM1_P11_S1	The agreements are typically long term, and usually contain provisions permitting termination by either party if there are significant breaches which are not cured within a reasonable period of time.
355948_18_ITEM1_P11_S2	Although some of these agreements allow PMT to return inventory periodically, others do not, in which case PMT may have obsolete inventory that they cannot return to the supplier.
355948_18_ITEM1_P12_S0	PMT s suppliers provide warranty coverage for the products and allow return of defective products, including those returned to PMT by its customers.
355948_18_ITEM1_P12_S1	For information regarding the warranty reserves, see Note 3 Significant Accounting Policies of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
355948_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	In addition to third party products, we sell proprietary products principally under certain trade names we own including: Amperex , Cetron and National .
355948_18_ITEM1_P13_S1	Our proprietary products include thyratrons and rectifiers, power tubes, ignitrons, magnetrons, phototubes, microwave generators and liquid crystal display monitors.
355948_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	The materials used in the manufacturing process consist of glass bulbs and tubing, nickel, stainless steel and other metals, plastic and metal bases, ceramics and a wide variety of fabricated metal components.
355948_18_ITEM1_P14_S1	These materials are generally readily available, but some components may require long lead times for production, and some materials are subject to shortages or price fluctuations based on supply and demand.
355948_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial and medical original equipment manufacturers markets.
355948_18_ITEM1_P15_S1	Our engineers design, manufacture, source and support a full spectrum of solutions to match the needs of our customers.
355948_18_ITEM1_P15_S2	We offer long term availability and proven custom display solutions that include touch screens, protective panels, custom enclosures, all-in-ones, specialized cabinet finishes and application specific software packages and certification services.
355948_18_ITEM1_P15_S3	Our volume commitments are lower than those of the large display manufacturers, making us the ideal choice for companies with very specific design requirements.
355948_18_ITEM1_P15_S4	We partner with both private label manufacturing companies and leading branded hardware vendors to offer the highest quality display and touch solutions and customized computing platforms.
355948_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	We have long-standing relationships with key component and finished goods manufacturers and several key ISO 9001 and ISO 13485 certified Asian display manufacturers that manufacture products to our specifications.
355948_18_ITEM1_P16_S1	We believe supplier relationships, combined with our engineering design and manufacturing capabilities and private label partnerships, allow us to maintain a well-balanced and technologically advanced offering of customer specific display solutions.
355948_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_18_ITEM1_P17_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts for CT and MRI systems; replacement CT and MRI tubes; CT service training; MRI coils, cold heads and RF amplifiers; hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; flat panel detector upgrades; and additional replacement solutions currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	We have employees, as well as authorized representatives, who are not our employees, selling our products primarily in regions where we do not have a direct sales presence.
355948_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	We offer various credit terms to qualifying customers as well as cash in advance and credit card terms.
355948_18_ITEM1_P20_S1	We establish credit limits for each customer and routinely review delinquent and aging accounts.
355948_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	We maintain approximately 110,700 part numbers in our product inventory database and we estimate that more than 90% of orders received by 6:00 p.m. local time are shipped complete the same day for stock product.
355948_18_ITEM1_P21_S1	Customers can access our products on our web sites, www.rell.com , www.rellhealthcare.com, www.canvys.com, www.rellpower.com and www.rellaser.com, through electronic data interchange, or by telephone.

355948_18_ITEM1_P22_S1	Information on stock availability, pricing in local currency, cross-reference information, customers and market analyses are obtainable throughout the entire distribution network.
