355948_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Investors should consider carefully the following risk factors in addition to the other information included and incorporated by reference in this Annual Report on Form 10-K that we believe are applicable to our businesses and the industries in which we operate.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	While we believe we have identified the key risk factors affecting our businesses, there may be additional risks and uncertainties that are not presently known or that are not currently believed to be significant that may adversely affect our results of operations.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	A significant portion of our cash, cash equivalents and investments are held by our foreign subsidiaries and could affect future liquidity needs.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	As of June 2, 2018, $34.6 million, or approximately 57% of our cash and cash equivalents was held by our foreign subsidiaries.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Some of these subsidiaries are located in jurisdictions that require foreign government approval before a cash repatriation can occur.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	In addition, under current tax law, repatriation of this cash may trigger significant adverse tax consequences in the U.S.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Our liquidity requirements could necessitate transfers of existing cash balances between our subsidiaries or to the United States.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P3_S1	While we intend to use some of the cash held outside the United States to fund our international operations and growth, when we encounter a significant need for liquidity domestically or at a particular location that we cannot fulfill through other internal or external sources, we may experience unfavorable tax, earnings and liquidity consequences due to cash transfers.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P3_S2	These adverse consequences would occur, for example, if the transfer of cash into the United Sates is taxed and no offsetting foreign tax credit or net operating loss carryforward is available to offset the U.S. tax liability, resulting in lower earnings and liquidity.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We may not achieve our plan for sales growth and margin targets.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We have established both margin and expense targets to grow our sales with new and existing customers.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P5_S1	If we do not achieve our growth objectives, the complexity of our global infrastructure makes it difficult to leverage our fixed cost structure to align with the size of our operations.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Factors that could have a significant effect on our ability to achieve these goals include the following:
355948_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Limitations on our ability to leverage our support-function cost structure while maintaining an adequate structure to achieve our growth objectives.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We have historically incurred significant charges for inventory obsolescence, and may incur similar charges in the future.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We maintain significant inventories in an effort to ensure that customers have a reliable source of supply.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Our products generally support industrial machinery powered by tube technology.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	As technology evolves and companies replace this capital equipment, the market for our products potentially declines.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P8_S3	In addition, the market for many of our other products changes rapidly resulting from the development of new technologies, evolving industry standards, frequent new product introductions by some of our suppliers and changing end-user demand, which can contribute to the decline in value or obsolescence of our inventory.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We do not have many long-term supply contracts with our customers.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P9_S1	If we fail to anticipate the changing needs of our customers or we do not accurately forecast customer demand, our customers may not place orders with us, and we may accumulate significant inventories of products that we may be unable to sell or return to our vendors.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P9_S2	This may result in a decline in the value of our inventory.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We face competitive pressures that could have a material adverse effect on our business.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Our overall competitive position depends on a number of factors including price, engineering capability, vendor representation, product diversity, lead times and the level of customer service.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	There are very few vacuum tube competitors in the markets we serve.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P11_S2	There are also a limited number of Chinese manufacturers whose ability to produce vacuum tubes has progressed over the past several years.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The most significant competitive risk comes from technical obsolescence.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Canvys faces many competitors in the markets we serve.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Increased competition may result in price reductions, reduced margins, or a loss of market share, any of which could materially and adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial condition.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P13_S2	As we expand our business and pursue our growth initiatives, we may encounter increased competition from current and/or new competitors.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P13_S3	Our failure to maintain and enhance our competitive position could have a material adverse effect on our business.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	A single stockholder has voting control over us.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	As of July 23, 2018, Edward J. Richardson, our Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President, beneficially owned approximately 99% of the outstanding shares of our Class B common stock, representing approximately 66% of the voting power of the outstanding common stock.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P15_S1	This share ownership permits Mr. Richardson to exert control over the outcome of stockholder votes, including votes concerning the election of directors, by-law amendments, possible mergers, corporate control contests, and other significant corporate transactions.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We are dependent on a limited number of vendors to supply us with essential products.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our principal products are capacitors, vacuum tubes and related products, microwave generators and high voltage power supplies.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P17_S1	The products we supply are currently produced by a relatively small number of manufacturers.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P17_S2	One of our suppliers represented 15 percent of our total cost of sales.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Our success depends, in large part, on maintaining current vendor relationships and developing new relationships.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P17_S4	To the extent that our significant suppliers are unwilling or unable to continue to do business with us, extend lead times, limit supplies due to capacity constraints, or other factors, there could be a material adverse effect on our business.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	International operations represent a significant percentage of our business and present a variety of risks that could impact our results.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Because we source and sell our products worldwide, our business is subject to risks associated with doing business internationally.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	These risks include the costs and difficulties of managing foreign entities, limitations on the repatriation and investment of funds, cultural differences that affect customer preferences and business practices, unstable political or economic conditions, trade protection measures and import or export licensing requirements, and changes in tax laws.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We also face exposure to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates because we conduct business outside of the United States.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Price increases caused by currency exchange rate fluctuations may make our products less competitive or may have an adverse effect on our margins.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our international revenues and expenses generally are derived from sales and operations in currencies other than the U.S. dollar.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	Accordingly, when the U.S. dollar strengthens in relation to the base currencies of the countries in which we sell our products, our U.S. dollar reported net revenue and income would decrease.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P21_S2	We currently do not engage in any currency hedging transactions.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P21_S3	We cannot predict whether foreign currency exchange risks inherent in doing business in foreign countries will have a material adverse effect on our operations and financial results in the future.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We may need to raise additional funds through debt or equity financings in the future to fund our domestic operations and our broader corporate initiatives, which would dilute the ownership of our existing shareholders.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	If the cash generated by our domestic operations is not sufficient to fund our domestic operations and our broader corporate initiatives, such as stock repurchases, dividends, acquisitions, and other strategic opportunities, we may need to raise additional funds through public or private debt or equity financings, or we may need to obtain new credit facilities to the extent we are unable to, or choose not to, repatriate our overseas cash.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Such additional financing may not be available on terms favorable to us, or at all, and any new equity financings or offerings would dilute our current stockholders ownership interests in us.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P23_S2	Furthermore, lenders may not agree to extend us new, additional or continuing credit.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P23_S3	In any such case, our business, operating results or financial condition could be adversely impacted.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	In a non-binding referendum on the United Kingdom s membership in the European Union ( EU ) in June 2016, a majority of those who voted approved the United Kingdom s withdrawal from the EU.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Any withdrawal by the United Kingdom from the EU ( Brexit ) would occur after, or possible concurrently with, a process of negotiation regarding the future terms of the United Kingdom s relationship with the EU, which could result in the United Kingdom losing access to certain aspects of the single EU market and the global trade deals negotiated by the EU on behalf of its members.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P24_S2	The Brexit vote and the perceptions as to the impact of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom may adversely affect business activity, political stability and economic conditions in the United Kingdom, the EU and elsewhere.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	Any of these developments, or the perception that any of these developments are likely to occur, could have a material adverse effect on economic growth or business activity in the United Kingdom, the Eurozone, or the EU, and could result in the relocation of businesses, cause business interruptions, lead to economic recession or depression, and impact the stability of the financial markets, availability of credit, political systems or financial institutions and the financial and monetary system.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P24_S4	Given that we conduct a substantial portion of our business in the EU, these developments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, liquidity and results of operations.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P24_S5	The uncertainty concerning the timing and terms of the exit could also have a negative impact on the growth of the European economy and cause greater volatility in all of the global currencies that we currently use to transact business.

355948_18_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Our products may be found to be defective or our services performed may result in equipment or product damage and, as a result, warranty and/or product liability claims may be asserted against us.

355948_18_ITEM1A_P49_S5	Any infringement claim brought against us, regardless of the duration, outcome or size of damage award, could result in substantial cost, divert our management s attention, be time consuming to defend, result in significant damage awards, cause product shipment delays, or require us to enter into royalty or other licensing agreements.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P50_S0	Additionally, if an infringement claim is successful we may be required to pay damages or seek royalty or license arrangements which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms.

355948_18_ITEM1A_P52_S0	If we fail to maintain an effective system of internal controls or discover material weaknesses in our internal controls over financial reporting, we may not be able to detect fraud or report our financial results accurately or timely.

355948_18_ITEM1A_P54_S2	In addition, control procedures are designed to reduce rather than eliminate business risks.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P55_S0	If we fail to maintain an effective system of internal controls, or if management or our independent registered public accounting firm discovers material weaknesses in our internal controls, we may be unable to produce reliable financial reports or prevent fraud.

355948_18_ITEM1A_P62_S0	We may incur substantial operational costs or be required to change our business practices to comply with the recently adopted General Data Protection Regulation.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P63_S0	The EU adopted the General Data Protection Regulation ( GDPR ) which went into effect in May 2018.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P63_S1	The GDPR includes operational requirements for companies that receive or process personal data of residents of the European Union, including more robust documentation requirements for data protection compliance programs.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P63_S2	Specifically, the GDPR introduced numerous privacy-related changes for companies operating in the EU, including greater control for data subjects, increased data portability for EU consumers, and data breach notification requirements.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Although GDPR has already gone into effect, there is still considerable uncertainty as to how to interpret and implement many of its provisions.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P64_S1	Complying with the GDPR may cause us to incur substantial operational costs or require us to change our business practices in ways that we cannot currently predict.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P64_S2	Despite our efforts to bring our practices into compliance with the GDPR, we may not be successful.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P64_S3	Non-compliance could result in proceedings against us by governmental entities, customers, data subjects or others.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P64_S4	Fines of up to 20 million euros or up to 4% of the annual global revenue of the noncompliant company, whichever is greater, may be imposed for violations of certain of the GDPR s requirements.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P65_S0	New tariffs and the evolving trade policy dispute between the United States and China may adversely affect our business.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P66_S0	On August 14, 2017, President Trump instructed the U.S. Trade Representative ( USTR ) to determine under Section 301 of the U.S. Trade Act of 1974 (the Trade Act ) whether to investigate China s law, policies, practices or actions that may be unreasonable or discriminatory and that may be harming American intellectual property rights, innovation or technology development.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P66_S1	On March 22, 2018, based upon the results of its investigation, the USTR published a report finding that the acts, policies and practices of the Chinese government are unreasonable or discriminatory and burden or restrict U.S. commerce.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P67_S0	On March 8, 2018, President Trump imposed significant tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from a number of countries, including China.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P67_S1	Subsequently, the USTR announced an initial proposed list of 1,300 goods imported from China that could be subject to additional tariffs and initiated a dispute with the World Trade Organization against China for alleged unfair trade practices.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P68_S0	On June 15, 2018, the USTR announced a list of products subject to additional tariffs.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P68_S1	The list focused on products from industrial sectors that contribute to or benefit from the Made in China 2025 industrial policy.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P69_S0	The list of products consists of two sets of tariff lines.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P69_S1	The first set contains 818 tariff lines for which Customs and Border Protection will begin collecting the additional duties on July 6, 2018.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P69_S2	This list includes some of our products.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P70_S0	The second set contains 284 proposed tariff lines that remain subject to further review.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P71_S0	These new tariffs and the evolving trade policy dispute between the United States and China may have a significant impact on the industries in which we participate.
355948_18_ITEM1A_P71_S1	A trade war between the United States and China or other governmental action related to tariffs or international trade agreements or policies has the potential to adversely impact demand for our products, our costs, customers, suppliers and/or the United States economy or certain sectors thereof and, thus, to adversely impact our businesses and results of operations.

355948_18_ITEM7_P4_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value flat panel detector solutions, replacement parts, tubes and service training for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_18_ITEM7_P4_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_18_ITEM7_P4_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_18_ITEM7_P4_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics, and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing, and visual technology solutions.
355948_18_ITEM7_P5_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical, and communication applications.
355948_18_ITEM7_P6_S0	On June 15, 2015, Richardson Electronics, Ltd ( the Company ) acquired certain assets of International Medical Equipment and Services, Inc. ( IMES ) for a purchase price of $12.2 million.
355948_18_ITEM7_P6_S1	This included the purchase of inventory, receivables, fixed assets, and certain other assets of the Company.
355948_18_ITEM7_P6_S2	The Company did not acquire any liabilities of IMES.
355948_18_ITEM7_P6_S3	The total consideration paid excludes transaction costs.
355948_18_ITEM7_P7_S0	IMES, based in South Carolina, provides reliable, cost-saving solutions worldwide for major brands of CT and MRI equipment.
355948_18_ITEM7_P7_S1	This acquisition positions Richardson Healthcare to provide cost effective diagnostic imaging replacement parts and training to hospitals, diagnostic imaging centers, medical institutions and independent service organizations.
355948_18_ITEM7_P7_S2	IMES offers an extensive selection of replacement parts, as well as an interactive training center, on-site test bays and experienced technicians who provide 24/7 customer support.
355948_18_ITEM7_P7_S3	Replacement parts are readily available and triple tested to provide peace of mind when uptime is critical.
355948_18_ITEM7_P8_S0	IMES core operations have remained in South Carolina.
355948_18_ITEM7_P8_S1	Richardson Healthcare plans to expand IMES replacement parts and training offerings geographically leveraging the Company s global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM7_P8_S2	During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, IMES opened up their first foreign location in Amsterdam.
355948_18_ITEM7_P9_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_18_ITEM7_P10_S0	Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ) combines our core engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tube business with new RF and power technologies.
355948_18_ITEM7_P10_S1	As a manufacturer and authorized distributor, PMT s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_18_ITEM7_P10_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics and aftermarket technical service and repair all through our existing global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM7_P11_S0	PMT s focus is on products for power, RF and microwave applications for customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_18_ITEM7_P11_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar and radiation oncology.
355948_18_ITEM7_P11_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_18_ITEM7_P12_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial and medical original equipment manufacturers markets.
355948_18_ITEM7_P12_S1	Our engineers design, manufacture, source and support a full spectrum of solutions to match the needs of our customers.
355948_18_ITEM7_P12_S2	We offer long term availability and proven custom display solutions that include touch screens, protective panels, custom enclosures, all-in-ones, specialized cabinet finishes and application specific software packages and certification services.
355948_18_ITEM7_P12_S3	Our volume commitments are lower than the large display manufacturers, making us the ideal choice for companies with very specific design requirements.
355948_18_ITEM7_P12_S4	We partner with both private label manufacturing companies and leading branded hardware vendors to offer the highest quality display and touch solutions and customized computing platforms.
355948_18_ITEM7_P13_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_18_ITEM7_P13_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts for CT and MRI systems; replacement CT and MRI tubes; CT service training; MRI coils, cold heads and RF amplifiers; hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; flat panel detector upgrades; and additional replacement solutions currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_18_ITEM7_P14_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_18_ITEM7_P15_S0	We currently have operations in the following geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe and Latin America.

355948_18_ITEM7_P37_S2	The difference between the effective tax rates as compared to the U.S. federal statutory rate of 29.2% during 2018 and 34% during 2017 and 2016 is primarily driven by the impact of recording a valuation allowance against all of our U.S. state and federal net deferred tax assets, repatriation of foreign earnings, changes in our geographical distribution of income (loss) and our recording of uncertain tax positions with respect to ASC 740-30, Income Taxes - Other Considerations or Special Areas ( ASC 740-30 ).
355948_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	On December 22, 2017, the U.S. government enacted new tax legislation, Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the Act ).
355948_18_ITEM7_P38_S1	The primary provisions of the Act expected to impact the Company in fiscal 2018 are a reduction to the U.S. corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21% and a transition from a worldwide corporate tax system to a territorial tax system.
355948_18_ITEM7_P38_S2	The reduction in the corporate income tax rate requires the Company to remeasure its net deferred tax assets to the new corporate tax rate and the transition to a territorial tax system requires payment of a one-time tax on deemed repatriation of undistributed and previously untaxed non-U.S. earnings.
355948_18_ITEM7_P38_S3	Primarily as a result of those provisions of the Act, the Company recorded a deferred remeasurement impact of approximately $1.6 million, which was fully offset by the valuation allowance movement.
355948_18_ITEM7_P38_S4	Additionally, the estimated deemed earnings repatriation tax, net of available foreign tax credits brought back as part of the deemed repatriation, was $3.5 million.
355948_18_ITEM7_P38_S5	The Company does not anticipate any cash tax payments due to the foreign tax credit carryforwards available to fully offset the provisional deemed repatriation tax.
355948_18_ITEM7_P39_S0	The 21% corporate income tax rate was effective January 1, 2018.
355948_18_ITEM7_P39_S1	Based on the Company s June 2, 2018 fiscal year end, the U.S. statutory income tax rate for fiscal 2018 will be approximately 29.2%.
355948_18_ITEM7_P40_S0	The tax impact recorded for the Act for fiscal 2018 is provisional as outlined below and may change.
355948_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	The Company completed a preliminary assessment of earnings that could be repatriated based on reinvestment needs of non-U.S. operations and earnings available for repatriation.
355948_18_ITEM7_P41_S1	The estimated withholding tax that would be incurred from the repatriation of those earnings was included in fiscal 2018 provisional income tax expense.
355948_18_ITEM7_P41_S2	The Company continues to analyze the provisions of the Act addressing the net deferred tax asset remeasurement and its calculations, the deemed earnings repatriation, including the determination of undistributed non-U.S. earnings, and evaluate potential Company actions.
355948_18_ITEM7_P41_S3	In addition, the Company continues to monitor potential legislative action and regulatory interpretations of the Act.
355948_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	Based on the effective date of certain provisions, the Company will be subject to additional requirements of the Act beginning in fiscal 2019.
355948_18_ITEM7_P42_S1	Those provisions include a tax on global intangible low-taxed income (GILTI), a tax determined by base erosion and anti-avoidance tax (BEAT) related to certain payments between a U.S. corporation and foreign related entities, a limitation of certain executive compensation, a deduction for foreign derived intangible income (FDII) and interest expense limitations.
355948_18_ITEM7_P42_S2	The Company has not completed its analysis of those provisions and the estimated impact.
355948_18_ITEM7_P42_S3	The Company also has not determined its accounting policy to treat the taxes due on GILTI as a period cost or include in the determination of deferred taxes.
355948_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	In December 2017, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 118 that allows for a measurement period up to one year after the enactment date of the Act to complete the accounting requirements.
355948_18_ITEM7_P43_S1	The Company will complete the adjustments related to the Act within the allowed period.

355948_18_ITEM7_P82_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_18_ITEM7_P83_S0	In January 2017, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2017-04 ( ASU 2017-04 ), Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
355948_18_ITEM7_P83_S1	ASU 2017-04 eliminates step 2 from the goodwill impairment test as defined in ASU 2011-08.
355948_18_ITEM7_P83_S2	As amended, the goodwill impairment test will consist of one-step comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
355948_18_ITEM7_P83_S3	An entity should recognize a goodwill impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value.
355948_18_ITEM7_P83_S4	An entity may still perform the optional qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
355948_18_ITEM7_P84_S0	ASU 2017-04 will be effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019.
355948_18_ITEM7_P84_S1	ASU 2017-04 is required to be applied prospectively and early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
355948_18_ITEM7_P84_S2	The Company elected to early adopt ASU 2017-04 for our fiscal 2018 annual impairment test.
355948_18_ITEM7_P85_S0	During the fourth quarter of each fiscal year, our goodwill balances are reviewed for impairment using the first day of our fourth quarter as the measurement date.
355948_18_ITEM7_P85_S1	If after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances, we determine that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then we test for impairment through the application of a fair value based test.
355948_18_ITEM7_P85_S2	After reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in ASU 2011-08, we determined that it was more likely than not that the fair value for the IMES reporting unit was less than its carrying value.
355948_18_ITEM7_P85_S3	Accordingly, we performed the quantitative impairment test using the income method, which is based on a discounted future cash flow approach that uses the significant assumptions of projected revenue, projected operational profit, terminal growth rates and the cost of capital.
355948_18_ITEM7_P85_S4	The Company used a weighted average cost of capital of 19% for these cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM7_P85_S5	The Guideline Public Company Method was also included in the goodwill impairment study.
355948_18_ITEM7_P86_S0	The Company engaged a third party to assist with the goodwill impairment testing.
355948_18_ITEM7_P86_S1	Management concluded that the results of our goodwill impairment test as of March 4, 2018 indicated that the value of goodwill attributed to our IMES reporting unit was not impaired due to its fair value exceeded its carrying value.
355948_18_ITEM7_P86_S2	In the three years since the acquisition, the Company has made significant investments in the IMES business, including capital expenditures and inventory, that are expected to increase IMES product offerings and result in increased future sales, operating profits and cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM7_P87_S0	Although we believe our projected future operating results and cash flows and related estimates regarding fair values were based on reasonable assumptions, historically, projected operating results and cash flows have not always been achieved.
355948_18_ITEM7_P87_S1	As of the first day of our fourth quarter, we determined that our IMES reporting unit had an estimated fair value in excess of its carrying value of at least 8.0%.
355948_18_ITEM7_P87_S2	Factors considered were the historical performance of the reporting unit, forecasted financials for the following ten years and comparable publically held companies.
355948_18_ITEM7_P87_S3	Management s projections used to estimate cash flows included increasing sales volumes from new product offerings, expanded sales into new geographies, and operational improvements designed to reduce costs.
355948_18_ITEM7_P87_S4	While all product lines are expected to grow, new product offerings are the largest component of the sales growth with more than 50% of future sales projected to be from new product offerings.
355948_18_ITEM7_P88_S0	Changes in any of the significant assumptions used, including if the Company does not successfully achieve its operating plan, which is largely dependent on sales from new product offerings, can materially affect the expected cash flows, and such impacts could result in a material non-cash impairment charge of goodwill and other long lived assets.
355948_18_ITEM7_P89_S0	Potential events or changes in circumstances that could reasonably be expected to negatively affect key assumptions are deterioration in general market conditions or the environment in which the reporting unit or entity operates, an increased competitive environment in which the reporting unit or entity operates or other relevant entity-specific events such as market acceptance of our new CT tubes and other new product offerings, approvals to sell in foreign markets, and changes in management or key personnel.
355948_18_ITEM7_P90_S0	Intangible assets are initially recorded at their fair market values determined on quoted market prices in active markets, if available, or recognized valuation models.
355948_18_ITEM7_P90_S1	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized over their useful lives either on a straight-line basis or over their projected future cash flows and are tested for impairment when events or changes in circumstances occur that indicate possible impairment.
355948_18_ITEM7_P91_S0	Our intangible assets represent the fair value for trade name, customer relationships, non-compete agreements and technology acquired in connection with the acquisition.
355948_18_ITEM7_P92_S0	We review property and equipment, definite-lived intangible assets and other long-lived assets for impairment whenever adverse events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amounts of such assets may not be recoverable.
355948_18_ITEM7_P93_S0	If adverse events do occur, our impairment review is based on an undiscounted cash flow analysis at the lowest level at which cash flows of the long-lived assets are largely independent of other groups of our assets and liabilities.
355948_18_ITEM7_P93_S1	This analysis requires management judgment with respect to changes in technology, the continued success of product lines and future volume, revenue and expense growth rates.
355948_18_ITEM7_P93_S2	We conduct annual reviews for idle and underutilized equipment and review business plans for possible impairment.
355948_18_ITEM7_P94_S0	Impairment occurs when the carrying value of the assets exceeds the future undiscounted cash flows expected to be earned by the use of the asset or asset group.
355948_18_ITEM7_P94_S1	When impairment is indicated, the estimated future cash flows are then discounted to determine the estimated fair value of the asset or asset group and an impairment charge is recorded for the difference between the carrying value and the estimated fair value.
355948_18_ITEM7_P95_S0	Additionally, we also evaluate the remaining useful life each reporting period to determine whether events and circumstances warrant a revision to the remaining period of depreciation or amortization.
355948_18_ITEM7_P96_S0	If the estimate of a long lived asset s remaining useful life is changed, the remaining carrying amount of the asset is amortized prospectively over that revised remaining useful life.
355948_18_ITEM7_P97_S0	We accrue a liability for loss contingencies when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
355948_18_ITEM7_P97_S1	When only a range of possible loss can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_18_ITEM7_P97_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_18_ITEM7_P98_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_18_ITEM7_P99_S0	We recognize deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the differences between financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of assets and liabilities.
355948_18_ITEM7_P99_S1	We regularly review our deferred tax assets for recoverability and determine the need for a valuation allowance based on a number of factors, including both positive and negative evidence.
355948_18_ITEM7_P99_S2	These factors include historical taxable income or loss, projected future taxable income or loss, the expected timing of the reversals of existing temporary differences and the implementation of tax planning strategies.
355948_18_ITEM7_P99_S3	In circumstances where we, or any of our affiliates, have incurred three years of cumulative losses which constitute significant negative evidence, positive evidence of equal or greater significance is needed to overcome the negative evidence before a tax benefit is recognized for deductible temporary differences and loss carryforwards.
355948_18_ITEM7_P99_S4	See Note 9 Income Taxes of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for further information.
355948_18_ITEM7_P100_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09 ( ASU 2014-09 ), Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which amends guidance for revenue recognition.
355948_18_ITEM7_P100_S1	ASU 2014-09 is principles based guidance that can be applied to all contracts with customers, enhancing comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions and capital markets.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that entities should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S1	The guidance details the steps entities should apply to achieve the core principle.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S2	In August 2015, the FASB issued an amendment to defer the effective date for all entities by one year.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S3	For public entities, ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S4	Early adoption is permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S5	Companies have the option of using either a full or modified retrospective approach in applying this standard.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S6	During fiscal 2016 and 2017, the FASB issued four additional updates which further clarify the guidance provided in ASU 2014-09.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S7	We have undertaken a detailed analysis of our various contracts with customers and revenue streams, including engaging a third party to assist management in evaluating the impact of this new standard on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S8	The Company s management has elected to adopt the amendments in ASU 2014-09 on a modified retrospective basis; whereas any cumulative effect of adopting this guidance will be recognized as an adjustment to its opening balance of retained earnings.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S9	Prior periods will not be retrospectively adjusted.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S10	The Company does not expect the implementation of ASU 2014-09 and the related amendments to have a material impact on the timing, amount or characterization of revenue recognized by the Company.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S11	For most of our revenue, we will continue to recognize revenue when title to the goods transfers to the customer, as this is generally when control transfers to the customer.
355948_18_ITEM7_P101_S12	While we expect the impact of these new standards will be immaterial to our financial statements, upon adoption, we will include the expanded disclosures required by the new standards.
355948_18_ITEM7_P102_S0	Pursuant to the Company s adoption of the standard it anticipates expanding its disclosures in the consolidated financial statements for revenue recognition, assets and liabilities relating to contracts with customers, the nature of the Company s performance obligations and the manner by which the Company determines and allocates transaction prices and variable consideration to its performance obligations and the significant judgments inherent in its revenue recognition policies.
355948_18_ITEM7_P103_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11 ( ASU 2015-11 ), Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
355948_18_ITEM7_P103_S1	ASU 2015-11 requires inventory within the scope of the ASU (e.g., first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) or average cost) to be measured using the lower of cost and net realizable value.
355948_18_ITEM7_P103_S2	Inventory excluded from the scope of the ASU (i.e., last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) or the retail inventory method) will continue to be measured at the lower of cost or market.
355948_18_ITEM7_P103_S3	The ASU also amends some of the other guidance in Topic 330, Inventory, to more clearly articulate the requirements for the measurement and disclosure of inventory.
355948_18_ITEM7_P103_S4	However, those amendments are not intended to result in any changes to current practice.
355948_18_ITEM7_P104_S0	ASU 2015-11 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_18_ITEM7_P104_S1	The Company adopted ASU 2015-11 in fiscal 2018 and there was no material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_18_ITEM7_P105_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02 ( ASU 2016-02 ), Leases.
355948_18_ITEM7_P105_S1	ASU 2016-02 establishes a right-of-use ( ROU ) model that requires a lessee to record an ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer than 12 months.
355948_18_ITEM7_P105_S2	Leases will be classified as either finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the income statement.
355948_18_ITEM7_P106_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
355948_18_ITEM7_P107_S0	A modified retrospective transition approach is required for lessees for capital and operating leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in the financial statements, with certain practical expedients available.
355948_18_ITEM7_P107_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of ASU 2016-02 on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_18_ITEM7_P107_S2	Upon adoption, the Company expects that the amounts recognized for the ROU asset and lease liability in the balance sheets may be material.
355948_18_ITEM7_P108_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-09 ( ASU 2016-09 ), Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting , a new accounting standard update intended to simplify several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment transactions including: income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities and classification on the statement of cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM7_P108_S1	Specifically, the ASU 2016-09 requires that excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies (the difference between the deduction for tax purposes and the compensation cost recognized for financial reporting purposes) be recognized as income tax expense or benefit in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss), introducing a new element of volatility to the provision for income taxes.
355948_18_ITEM7_P108_S2	This update is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_18_ITEM7_P108_S3	The Company adopted ASU 2016-09 on May 28, 2017.
355948_18_ITEM7_P108_S4	Effective with the adoption of the ASU all share-based awards continue to be accounted for as equity awards, excess tax benefits recognized on stock-based compensation expense are reflected in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss) as a component of the provision for income taxes on a prospective basis, excess tax benefits recognized on stock-based compensation expense are classified as an operating activity in the consolidated statements of cash flows on a prospective basis and the Company has elected to continue to estimate expected forfeitures over the course of a vesting period.
355948_18_ITEM7_P108_S5	The adoption of ASU 2016-09 had no impact on the retained earnings, other components of equity or net assets as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-13, Financial Instruments Credit Losses (Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S1	ASU 2016-13 introduces a new forward-looking approach, based on expected losses, to estimate credit losses on certain types of financial instruments, including trade receivables.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S2	The estimate of expected credit losses will require entities to incorporate considerations of historical information, current information and reasonable and supportable forecasts.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S3	This ASU also expands the disclosure requirements to enable users of financial statements to understand the entity s assumptions, models and methods for estimating expected credit losses.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S4	For public business entities, ASU 2016-13 is effective for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2019, and the guidance is to be applied using the modified-retrospective approach.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S5	Earlier adoption is permitted for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2018.
355948_18_ITEM7_P109_S6	The Company is currently in the process of evaluating the impact of adoption on its consolidated financial statements.

355948_18_ITEM7_P111_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU No. 2017-04 ( ASU 2017-04 ), Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
355948_18_ITEM7_P111_S1	ASU 2017-04 eliminates step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
355948_18_ITEM7_P111_S2	As amended, the goodwill impairment test will consist of one-step comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
355948_18_ITEM7_P111_S3	An entity should recognize a goodwill impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value.
355948_18_ITEM7_P111_S4	An entity may still perform the optional qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
355948_18_ITEM7_P112_S0	ASU 2017-04 will be effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019.
355948_18_ITEM7_P112_S1	ASU 2017-04 is required to be applied prospectively and early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
355948_18_ITEM7_P112_S2	The Company elected to early adopt ASU 2017-04 for our fiscal 2018 annual impairment test.

355948_18_ITEM7_P113_S1	The guidance permits entities to reclassify tax effects stranded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income as a result of tax reform to retained earnings.

355948_18_ITEM7_P114_S0	Early adoption is permitted in annual and interim periods and can be applied retrospectively or in the period of adoption.

355948_18_ITEM7_P115_S1	The update clarifies that in a company s financial statements that include the reporting period in which the Act was enacted, the company must first reflect the income tax effects of the Act in which the accounting under GAAP is complete.
355948_18_ITEM7_P116_S0	These amounts would not be provisional amounts.

355948_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We are exposed to many different market risks with the various industries we serve.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The primary financial risk we are exposed to is foreign currency exchange, as certain operations, assets and liabilities of ours are denominated in foreign currencies.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P0_S2	We manage these risks through normal operating and financing activities.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The interpretation and analysis of these disclosures should not be considered in isolation since such variances in exchange rates would likely influence other economic factors.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Such factors, which are not readily quantifiable, would likely also affect our operations.

355948_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Even though we take into account current foreign currency exchange rates at the time an order is taken, our financial statements, denominated in a non-U.S. functional currency, are subject to foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Our foreign denominated assets and liabilities are cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, inventory, accounts payable and intercompany receivables and payables, as we conduct business in countries of the European Union, Asia/Pacific and, to a lesser extent, Canada and Latin America.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P3_S1	We do manage foreign exchange exposures by using currency clauses in certain sales contracts and we also have local debt to offset asset exposures.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P3_S2	We have not used any derivative instruments nor entered into any forward contracts in fiscal 2018, fiscal 2017 or fiscal 2016.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Had the U.S. dollar changed unfavorably 10% against various foreign currencies, foreign denominated net sales would have been lower by an estimated $10.4 million during fiscal 2018, an estimated $9.1 million during fiscal 2017 and an estimated $9.9 million during fiscal 2016.
355948_18_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Total assets would have declined by an estimated $5.6 million as of the fiscal year ended June 2, 2018 and an estimated $5.2 million as of the fiscal year ended May 27, 2017, while the total liabilities would have decreased by an estimated $1.0 million as of the fiscal year ended June 2, 2018 and an estimated $0.9 million as of the fiscal year ended May 27, 2017.

355948_18_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Such factors, which are not readily quantifiable, would likely also affect our operations.
355948_18_ITEM8_P0_S0	Richardson Electronics, Ltd. is a leading global provider of engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tubes and related consumables; power conversion and RF and microwave components; high value flat panel detector solutions, replacement parts, tubes and service training for diagnostic imaging equipment; and customized display solutions.
355948_18_ITEM8_P0_S1	We serve customers in the alternative energy, healthcare, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_18_ITEM8_P0_S2	The Company s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_18_ITEM8_P0_S3	The Company provides solutions and adds value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics and aftermarket technical service and repair through its global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM8_P1_S0	Our products include electron tubes and related components, microwave generators, subsystems used in semiconductor manufacturing and visual technology solutions.
355948_18_ITEM8_P1_S1	These products are used to control, switch or amplify electrical power signals, or are used as display devices in a variety of industrial, commercial, medical and communication applications.
355948_18_ITEM8_P2_S0	We have three operating and reportable segments, which we define as follows:
355948_18_ITEM8_P3_S0	Power and Microwave Technologies Group ( PMT ) combines our core engineered solutions, power grid and microwave tube business with new RF and power technologies.
355948_18_ITEM8_P3_S1	As a manufacturer and authorized distributor, PMT s strategy is to provide specialized technical expertise and engineered solutions based on our core engineering and manufacturing capabilities.
355948_18_ITEM8_P3_S2	We provide solutions and add value through design-in support, systems integration, prototype design and manufacturing, testing, logistics and aftermarket technical service and repair all through our existing global infrastructure.
355948_18_ITEM8_P4_S0	PMT s focus is on products for power, RF and microwave applications for customers in alternative energy, aviation, broadcast, communications, industrial, marine, medical, military, scientific and semiconductor markets.
355948_18_ITEM8_P4_S1	PMT focuses on various applications including broadcast transmission, CO2 laser cutting, diagnostic imaging, dielectric and induction heating, high energy transfer, high voltage switching, plasma, power conversion, radar and radiation oncology.
355948_18_ITEM8_P4_S2	PMT also offers its customers technical services for both microwave and industrial equipment.
355948_18_ITEM8_P5_S0	Canvys provides customized display solutions serving the corporate enterprise, financial, healthcare, industrial and medical original equipment manufacturers markets.
355948_18_ITEM8_P5_S1	Our engineers design, manufacture, source and support a full spectrum of solutions to match the needs of our customers.
355948_18_ITEM8_P5_S2	We offer long term availability and proven custom display solutions that include touch screens, protective panels, custom enclosures, all-in-ones, specialized cabinet finishes and application specific software packages and certification services.
355948_18_ITEM8_P5_S3	We partner with both private label manufacturing companies and leading branded hardware vendors to offer the highest quality display and touch solutions and customized computing platforms.
355948_18_ITEM8_P6_S0	Healthcare manufactures, refurbishes and distributes high value replacement parts for the healthcare market including hospitals, medical centers, asset management companies, independent service organizations and multi-vendor service providers.
355948_18_ITEM8_P6_S1	Products include Diagnostic Imaging replacement parts for CT and MRI systems; replacement CT and MRI tubes; CT service training; MRI coils, cold heads and RF amplifiers; hydrogen thyratrons, klystrons, magnetrons; flat panel detector upgrades; and additional replacement solutions currently under development for the diagnostic imaging service market.
355948_18_ITEM8_P7_S0	Through a combination of newly developed products and partnerships, service offerings and training programs, we believe we can help our customers improve efficiency and deliver better clinical outcomes while lowering the cost of healthcare delivery.
355948_18_ITEM8_P8_S0	We currently have operations in the following major geographic regions: North America, Asia/Pacific, Europe and Latin America.

355948_18_ITEM8_P15_S1	Management continuously evaluates its critical accounting policies and estimates, including the allowance for doubtful accounts, revenue recognition, inventory obsolescence, goodwill and other intangible assets, loss contingencies and income taxes.

355948_18_ITEM8_P21_S1	When only a range of possible loss can be established, the most probable amount in the range is accrued.
355948_18_ITEM8_P21_S2	If no amount within this range is a better estimate than any other amount within the range, the minimum amount in the range is accrued.
355948_18_ITEM8_P22_S0	If we determine that there is at least a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred, we will include a disclosure describing the contingency.
355948_18_ITEM8_P23_S0	Our product sales are recognized as revenue upon shipment, when title passes to the customer, when delivery has occurred or services have been rendered and when collectability is reasonably assured.
355948_18_ITEM8_P23_S1	We also record estimated discounts and returns based on our historical experience.

355948_18_ITEM8_P23_S4	Our customers are under no obligation to compensate us for designing the products we sell.

355948_18_ITEM8_P37_S0	Goodwill and Intangible Assets: We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_18_ITEM8_P38_S0	In January 2017, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2017-04 ( ASU 2017-04 ), Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
355948_18_ITEM8_P38_S1	ASU 2017-04 eliminates step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
355948_18_ITEM8_P38_S2	As amended, the goodwill impairment test will consist of one-step comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
355948_18_ITEM8_P38_S3	An entity should recognize a goodwill impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value.
355948_18_ITEM8_P38_S4	An entity may still perform the optional qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
355948_18_ITEM8_P39_S0	ASU 2017-04 will be effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019.
355948_18_ITEM8_P39_S1	ASU 2017-04 is required to be applied prospectively and early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
355948_18_ITEM8_P39_S2	The Company elected to early adopt ASU 2017-04 for our fiscal 2018 annual impairment test.
355948_18_ITEM8_P40_S0	During the fourth quarter of each fiscal year, our goodwill balances are reviewed for impairment using the first day of our fourth quarter as the measurement date.
355948_18_ITEM8_P40_S1	If after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances, we determine that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then we test for impairment through the application of a fair value based test.
355948_18_ITEM8_P40_S2	We estimate the fair value of each of our reporting units based on projected future operating results, market approach and discounted cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM8_P41_S0	After reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in FASB ASC 350-20-35, we determined that it was more likely than not that the fair value for the IMES reporting unit was less than its carrying value.
355948_18_ITEM8_P41_S1	Accordingly, the quantitative goodwill impairment test as described in FASB ASC 350-20-35 was performed.
355948_18_ITEM8_P42_S0	We performed the quantitative impairment test using the income method, which is based on a discounted future cash flow approach that uses the significant assumptions of projected revenue, projected operational profit, terminal growth rates and the cost of capital.
355948_18_ITEM8_P42_S1	Refer to Note 7 Goodwill and Intangible Assets of the notes to our consolidated financial statements in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
355948_18_ITEM8_P43_S0	Intangible assets are initially recorded at their fair market values determined on quoted market prices in active markets, if available, or recognized valuation models.
355948_18_ITEM8_P43_S1	Intangible assets that have finite useful lives are amortized over their useful lives either on a straight-line basis or over their projected future cash flows and are tested for impairment when events or changes in circumstances occur that indicate possible impairment.
355948_18_ITEM8_P44_S0	Our intangible assets represent the fair value for trade name, customer relationships, non-compete agreements and technology acquired in connection with the acquisition.

355948_18_ITEM8_P76_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09 ( ASU 2014-09 ), Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which amends guidance for revenue recognition.
355948_18_ITEM8_P76_S1	ASU 2014-09 is principles based guidance that can be applied to all contracts with customers, enhancing comparability of revenue recognition practices across entities, industries, jurisdictions and capital markets.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that entities should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S1	The guidance details the steps entities should apply to achieve the core principle.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S2	In August 2015, the FASB issued an amendment to defer the effective date for all entities by one year.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S3	For public entities, ASU 2014-09 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S4	Early adoption is permitted as of annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S5	Companies have the option of using either a full or modified retrospective approach in applying this standard.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S6	During fiscal 2016 and 2017, the FASB issued four additional updates which further clarify the guidance provided in ASU 2014-09.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S7	We have undertaken a detailed analysis of our various contracts with customers and revenue streams, including engaging a third party to assist management in evaluating the impact of this new standard on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S8	The Company s management has elected to adopt the amendments in ASU 2014-09 on a modified retrospective basis; whereas any cumulative effect of adopting this guidance will be recognized as an adjustment to its opening balance of retained earnings.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S9	Prior periods will not be retrospectively adjusted.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S10	The Company does not expect the implementation of ASU 2014-09 and the related amendments to have a material impact on the timing, amount or characterization of revenue recognized by the Company.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S11	For most of our revenue, we will continue to recognize revenue when title to the goods transfers to the customer, as this is generally when control transfers to the customer.
355948_18_ITEM8_P77_S12	While we expect the impact of these new standards will be immaterial to our financial statements, upon adoption, we will include the expanded disclosures required by the new standards.
355948_18_ITEM8_P78_S0	Pursuant to the Company s adoption of the standard it anticipates expanding its disclosures in the consolidated financial statements for revenue recognition, assets and liabilities relating to contracts with customers, the nature of the Company s performance obligations and the manner by which the Company determines and allocates transaction prices and variable consideration to its performance obligations and the significant judgments inherent in its revenue recognition policies.
355948_18_ITEM8_P79_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11 ( ASU 2015-11 ), Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory.
355948_18_ITEM8_P79_S1	ASU 2015-11 requires inventory within the scope of the ASU (e.g., first-in, first-out ( FIFO ) or average cost) to be measured using the lower of cost and net realizable value.
355948_18_ITEM8_P79_S2	Inventory excluded from the scope of the ASU (i.e., last-in, first-out ( LIFO ) or the retail inventory method) will continue to be measured at the lower of cost or market.
355948_18_ITEM8_P79_S3	The ASU also amends some of the other guidance in Topic 330, Inventory, to more clearly articulate the requirements for the measurement and disclosure of inventory.
355948_18_ITEM8_P79_S4	However, those amendments are not intended to result in any changes to current practice.
355948_18_ITEM8_P80_S0	ASU 2015-11 is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_18_ITEM8_P80_S1	The Company adopted ASU 2015-11 in fiscal 2018 and there was no material impact on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_18_ITEM8_P81_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02 ( ASU 2016-02 ), Leases.
355948_18_ITEM8_P81_S1	ASU 2016-02 establishes a right-of-use ( ROU ) model that requires a lessee to record an ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer than 12 months.
355948_18_ITEM8_P81_S2	Leases will be classified as either finance or operating, with classification affecting the pattern of expense recognition in the income statement.
355948_18_ITEM8_P82_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
355948_18_ITEM8_P83_S0	A modified retrospective transition approach is required for lessees for capital and operating leases existing at, or entered into after, the beginning of the earliest comparative period presented in the financial statements, with certain practical expedients available.
355948_18_ITEM8_P83_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the potential impact of the adoption of ASU 2016-02 on the Company s consolidated financial statements.
355948_18_ITEM8_P83_S2	Upon adoption, the Company expects that the amounts recognized for the ROU asset and lease liability in the balance sheets may be material.
355948_18_ITEM8_P84_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-09 ( ASU 2016-09 ), Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting , a new accounting standard update intended to simplify several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment transactions including: income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities and classification on the statement of cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM8_P84_S1	Specifically, the ASU 2016-09 requires that excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies (the difference between the deduction for tax purposes and the compensation cost recognized for financial reporting purposes) be recognized as income tax expense or benefit in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss), introducing a new element of volatility to the provision for income taxes.
355948_18_ITEM8_P84_S2	This update is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
355948_18_ITEM8_P84_S3	The Company adopted ASU 2016-09 on May 28, 2017.
355948_18_ITEM8_P84_S4	Effective with the adoption of the ASU all share-based awards continue to be accounted for as equity awards, excess tax benefits recognized on stock-based compensation expense are reflected in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss) as a component of the provision for income taxes on a prospective basis, excess tax benefits recognized on stock-based compensation expense are classified as an operating activity in the consolidated statements of cash flows on a prospective basis and the Company has elected to continue to estimate expected forfeitures over the course of a vesting period.
355948_18_ITEM8_P84_S5	The adoption of ASU 2016-09 had no impact on the retained earnings, other components of equity or net assets as of the beginning of the period of adoption.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-13, Financial Instruments Credit Losses (Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S1	ASU 2016-13 introduces a new forward-looking approach, based on expected losses, to estimate credit losses on certain types of financial instruments, including trade receivables.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S2	The estimate of expected credit losses will require entities to incorporate considerations of historical information, current information and reasonable and supportable forecasts.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S3	This ASU also expands the disclosure requirements to enable users of financial statements to understand the entity s assumptions, models and methods for estimating expected credit losses.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S4	For public business entities, ASU 2016-13 is effective for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2019, and the guidance is to be applied using the modified-retrospective approach.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S5	Earlier adoption is permitted for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2018.
355948_18_ITEM8_P85_S6	The Company is currently in the process of evaluating the impact of adoption on its consolidated financial statements.

355948_18_ITEM8_P89_S1	The update clarifies that in a company s financial statements that include the reporting period in which the Act was enacted, the company must first reflect the income tax effects of the Act in which the accounting under GAAP is complete.

355948_18_ITEM8_P104_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events or circumstances indicate an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate, an adverse action or assessment by a regulator, unanticipated competition, loss of key personnel or a decision to sell or dispose of a reporting unit.
355948_18_ITEM8_P105_S0	In January 2017, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2017-04 ( ASU 2017-04 ), Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
355948_18_ITEM8_P105_S1	ASU 2017-04 eliminates step 2 from the goodwill impairment test as defined in ASU 2011-08.
355948_18_ITEM8_P105_S2	As amended, the goodwill impairment test will consist of one-step comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount.
355948_18_ITEM8_P105_S3	An entity should recognize a goodwill impairment charge for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the reporting unit s fair value.
355948_18_ITEM8_P105_S4	An entity may still perform the optional qualitative assessment for a reporting unit to determine if it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired.
355948_18_ITEM8_P106_S0	ASU 2017-04 will be effective for fiscal years and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2019.
355948_18_ITEM8_P106_S1	ASU 2017-04 is required to be applied prospectively and early adoption is permitted for interim or annual goodwill impairment tests performed on testing dates after January 1, 2017.
355948_18_ITEM8_P106_S2	The Company elected to early adopt ASU 2017-04 for our fiscal 2018 annual impairment test.
355948_18_ITEM8_P107_S0	On March 4, 2018, our goodwill balance was reviewed for impairment on a qualitative basis.
355948_18_ITEM8_P107_S1	We determined that it was more likely than not that the fair value of our IMES reporting unit was less than its carrying amount after reviewing the totality of events or circumstances as provided in FASB ASC 350-20-35.
355948_18_ITEM8_P107_S2	Accordingly, the quantitative goodwill impairment test as described in FASB ASC 350-20-35 was performed.
355948_18_ITEM8_P108_S0	We performed the quantitative impairment test using the income method, which is based on a discounted future cash flow approach that uses the significant assumptions of projected revenue, projected operational profit, terminal growth rates and the cost of capital.
355948_18_ITEM8_P108_S1	The Guideline Public Company Method was also included in the goodwill impairment study.
355948_18_ITEM8_P109_S0	The Company engaged a third party to assist with the goodwill impairment testing.
355948_18_ITEM8_P109_S1	Management concluded that the results of our goodwill impairment test as of March 4, 2018 indicated that the value of goodwill attributed to our IMES reporting unit was not impaired due to its fair value exceeded its carrying value.
355948_18_ITEM8_P109_S2	In the three years since the acquisition, the Company has made significant investments in the IMES business, including capital expenditures, new product development and inventory, that are expected to increase IMES product offerings and result in increased future sales, operating profits and cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S0	Although we believe our projected future operating results and cash flows and related estimates regarding fair values were based on reasonable assumptions, historically, projected operating results and cash flows have not always been achieved.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S1	As of the first day of our fourth quarter, we determined that our IMES reporting unit had an estimated fair value in excess of its carrying value of at least 8.0%.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S2	Factors considered in calculating the fair value of the reporting unit were the historical performance of the reporting unit, forecasted financials for the following ten years and comparable publically held companies.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S3	Management s projections used to estimate cash flows included increasing sales volumes from new product offerings, expanded sales into new geographies, and operational improvements designed to reduce costs.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S4	While all product lines are expected to grow, new product offerings are the largest component of the sales growth with more than 50% of future sales projected to be from new product offerings.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S5	The Company used a weighted average cost of capital of 19% for these cash flows.
355948_18_ITEM8_P110_S6	Changes in any of the significant assumptions used, including if the Company does not successfully achieve its operating plan, which is largely dependent on sales from new product offerings, can materially affect the expected cash flows, and such impacts could result in a material non-cash impairment charge of goodwill and potentially other long lived assets.
355948_18_ITEM8_P111_S0	Potential events or changes in circumstances that could reasonably be expected to negatively affect key assumptions are deterioration in general market conditions or the environment in which the reporting unit or entity operates, an increased competitive environment in which the reporting unit or entity operates or other relevant entity-specific events such as market acceptance of our new CT tubes and other new product offerings, approvals to sell in foreign markets, and changes in management or key personnel.

355948_18_ITEM8_P124_S0	On December 22, 2017, the U.S. government enacted new tax legislation, Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the Act ).
355948_18_ITEM8_P124_S1	The primary provisions of the Act expected to impact the Company in fiscal 2018 are a reduction to the U.S. corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21% and a transition from a worldwide corporate tax system to a territorial tax system.
355948_18_ITEM8_P124_S2	The reduction in the corporate income tax rate requires the Company to remeasure its net deferred tax assets to the new corporate tax rate and the transition to a territorial tax system requires payment of a one-time tax on deemed repatriation of undistributed and previously untaxed non-U.S. earnings.
355948_18_ITEM8_P124_S3	Primarily as a result of those provisions of the Act, the Company recorded a deferred remeasurement impact of approximately $1.6 million, which was fully offset by the valuation allowance movement.
355948_18_ITEM8_P124_S4	Additionally, the estimated deemed earnings repatriation tax, net of available foreign tax credits brought back as part of the deemed repatriation, was $3.5 million.
355948_18_ITEM8_P124_S5	The Company does not anticipate any cash tax payments due to the foreign tax credit carryforwards available to fully offset the provisional deemed repatriation tax.
355948_18_ITEM8_P125_S0	The 21% corporate income tax rate was effective January 1, 2018.
355948_18_ITEM8_P125_S1	Based on the Company s June 2, 2018 fiscal year end, the U.S. statutory income tax rate for fiscal 2018 will be approximately 29.2%.
355948_18_ITEM8_P126_S0	The tax impact recorded for the Act for fiscal 2018 is provisional as outlined below and may change.
355948_18_ITEM8_P127_S0	The Company completed a preliminary assessment of earnings that could be repatriated based on reinvestment needs of non-U.S. operations and earnings available for repatriation.
355948_18_ITEM8_P127_S1	The estimated withholding tax that would be incurred from the repatriation of those earnings was included in fiscal 2018 provisional income tax expense.
355948_18_ITEM8_P127_S2	The Company continues to analyze the provisions of the Act addressing the net deferred tax asset remeasurement and its calculations, the deemed earnings repatriation, including the determination of undistributed non-U.S. earnings, and evaluate potential Company actions.
355948_18_ITEM8_P127_S3	In addition, the Company continues to monitor potential legislative action and regulatory interpretations of the Act.
355948_18_ITEM8_P128_S0	Based on the effective date of certain provisions, the Company will be subject to additional requirements of the Act beginning in fiscal 2019.
355948_18_ITEM8_P128_S1	Those provisions include a tax on global intangible low-taxed income (GILTI), a tax determined by base erosion and anti-avoidance tax (BEAT) related to certain payments between a U.S. corporation and foreign related entities, a limitation of certain executive compensation, a deduction for foreign derived intangible income (FDII) and interest expense limitations.
355948_18_ITEM8_P128_S2	The Company has not completed its analysis of those provisions and the estimated impact.
355948_18_ITEM8_P128_S3	The Company also has not determined its accounting policy to treat the taxes due on GILTI as a period cost or include in the determination of deferred taxes.
355948_18_ITEM8_P129_S0	In December 2017, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 118 that allows for a measurement period up to one year after the enactment date of the Act to complete the accounting requirements.
355948_18_ITEM8_P129_S1	The Company will complete the adjustments related to the Act within the allowed period.
